London HENRY FROWDE OXFORD UNIVERSITY PRESS WAREHOUSE AMEN CORNER, E.C. New York MACMILLAN & CO., 66 FIFTH AVENUE
[The exterior of the Shrine at Delphi (see note on 63): the priestess comes forward and speaks.] [1-63. PROLOGUE. The priestess calls on all the gods connected with the shrine, then goes in, and returns terrified, describing the sight within, a blood-stained murderer on the central stone, and the dreadful Furies sleeping round.]

πρεσβεύω. 'I honour most; the superlative sense practically contained in the word accounts for gen. θεῶν. πρεσβεύω is rather a favourite word of Aeschylus. So line 21 Παλλὰς πρεσβεύεται, ‘has chief honour,' Cho. 488 πρῶτον τόνδε πρεσβεύσω τάφον, as here, Ag. 1300 ὁ δ᾽ ὕστατος τοῦ χρόνου πρεσβεύεται, is first in respect of time, Cho. 631 κακῶν πρεσβεύεται, is first of horrors.

πρωτόμαντιν. The Earth was naturally regarded as 'most ancient' of gods: and prophetic, perhaps because the ancient shrines of prophecy were so often caverns or mysterious chasms (e. g. Delphic chasm, the Sibyl's cave, the cave of Trophonios, etc.). Pausanias tells us (10.5. 5) that the Delphians affirmed their oracle to have originally belonged to the Earth. And Prom. 209 we have Faîa and Θέμις pro- phesying to Prometheus. ἐκ δὲ τῆς, ‘after her;' τῆς common Epic use of art. for demonst. frequent in Aesch., ἐκ τοῦ, ἐν δὲ τῷ, ἢ τοῖσιν ἢ τοῖς, etc.
The dramatic particle δή probably here merely anticipates ὡς λόγος τις.

μητρός, mother of Themis; not the general meaning Mother Earth. It is a striking evidence of the fluctuating character of these genealogies that the poet elsewhere (Prom. 209) speaks of Earth and Themis as the same; one form of many names.
Note ἔζετο with acc. Cf. Ag. 183 σέλμα σεμνὸν ἡμένων, 664 ναῦν ἐφέζετο.
λάχει, ‘lot;' vivid poetic for in the third place, third in order.

θελούσης, οὐδὲ πρὸς βίαν τινός, 'with her good will, neither in despite of any.' Aeschylus uses this stately emphasis because he is
following (or inventing) a different story from what was apparently the received version: for Pindar says (quoted by Schol.) that 'Apollo by force occupied Pytho:' and Eurip. (Iph. Τ. 1259) says, 'Apollo came and took away Themis daughter of Earth from the divine oracles.' But this savage and doubtless older story was not suitable to the poet's purpose: the sanctity and dignity of the oracle (ideas which are required for the plot) are averse from such violence.

The Titans were according to the oldest story six sons and six daughters of Ouranos and Gaia: the author of the Theogony gives the list (Hes. Theog. 134), mentioning both Themis and Phoibe. According to same ancient source (Theog. 403) Phoibe (by Koios the Titan) was mother of Leto, hence grandmother of Phoibos; and so by custom gave the infant Phoibos both 'a birthday gift' (7), and his name (8).
ἥ, she. Epic demonstrative use of ős, surviving in ἢ δ᾽ ὅς, ὃς δ᾽
ἔφη (' said he').
δίδωσι, gives it, the oracle.

γενέθλιον δόσιν. There were two birth-festivals at Athens-the ἀμφιδρόμια, when the infant was carried round the hearth on the seventh (or fifth day), and the δεκάτη, 'tenth-day festival, when it was named and formally recognised by the father. On both occasions, especially the latter, presents were given.
παρώνυμον, made like to hers.

λίμνη, the circular or rather oval tarn in the north of the island, often referred to by ancient writers (Eur. Ion 167, Iph. Taur. 1104, Herod. 2. 170, etc.), and apparently connected with the birth of Apollo.
χοιράς, 's back,hog lit., i.e. ridge or rock, of Mount Kynthos.
The 'ship-frequented shores of Pallas' are Attica, regarded as specially the land of Pallas Athene.

Delphi is called 'the shrine of Parnassus' as being at the foot of that Mountain. 11. 13, 14. The Athenians are called, in Aeschylus' grand style, 'the sons of Hephaistos, hewers of the road, making tame the wild land.' There was a 'sacred way' from Athens to Delphi, and Athenian tradition evidently affirmed that it had been made of old by Athenians for Apollo. The Schol. mentions an interesting ceremonial, plainly a survival, bearing on this tradition, that when Athens sent a mission to Delphi, the sacred ambassadors were preceded by men with axes. (The Boeotian Pindar, on the other hand, makes Apollo start from Tanagra in Boeotia, according to the Schol.).

παῖδες Ἡφαίστου, because Hephaistos was father of Erichthonios, mythical king of Athens. The title is peculiarly appropriate to the hewers of the way, as Hephaistos was the god who invented many of the tools and the arts of civilised life.
Making tame, i, e. evidently clearing and settling; not only (as Schol.) from robbers.'
Δελφός, the king and eponymous' hero of Delphians.
κτίζω, properly to build, a favourite word of Aeschylus, often used as a stately synonym for to make: e.g. Pers. 289 εὐνίδας ἔκτισσαν, Cho. 1060 ἐλεύθερόν σε κτίσει, Eum. 714 μηδ᾽ ἀκαρπώτους κτίσαι.
προφήτης, ‘the spokesman,' the interpreter of Zeus. So he says in a fragment (79) Ζεὺς ἐγκαθίει Λοξίᾳ θεσπίσματα. So Verg. A. 3. 251 'Quae Phoebo pater omnipotens, mihi Phoebus Apollo Prae- dixit.'

Παλλὰς προναία, ‘Pallas of the precincts;' the name of a temple of Athena near the great sanctuary of Apollo at Delphi. It is mentioned by Herodotus in this form (προνηΐη) 1.92, and there exist two Delphic inscriptions containing it (ΠΡΟΝΑΙA): but it seems to have been afterwards corrupted into πρόνοια, the shape in which the name of Athena at Delphi appears in Demosthenes (780), Aeschines (Ctes. 69), and Pausanias (10.8.7). Some people suppose two Delphic Athenas, προναία and πρόνοια: but this, though possible, is hardly likely. The learned Alexandrine poet Callimachus (250 B.C.) has the old form (προναίην, quoted by Schol.).

Κωρυκίς. The Korykian cavern was a remarkable cave high up in Parnassus, seven miles from Delphi: the cavern contains two large chambers 100 and 200 feet long respectively: it was the refuge of the Delphians in the Persian invasion (Herod. 8. 36), and more than once when their country was invaded. It was sacred to Pan and the nymphs.
φίλορνις, loved of birds, using the shelter for roosting and building.
φἀναστροφή, abode, haunt. The verb ἀναστρέφεσθαι is common for to be engaged in, to live ; ἐν φανερῷ, ἐν ᾿Αργει, ἐν μέσῳ, ἐν ξυμμαχίᾳ, etc. (versari Latin).

Βρόμιος, a common title of Bacchus. Aeschylus in glorifying Delphi fixes there the scene of the great vengeance of Bacchus on Pentheus. [Pentheus, king of Thebes, forbade and tried to prevent the worship of Bacchus; but the god drove mad with Bacchic frenzy the women, in- cluding Agaue Pentheus' mother, and they tore the king in pieces.] Euripides in the Bacchae makes Kithairon (between Attica and Boeotia) the scene, and Schol. says that Aeschylus himself also follows this tradition in the lost play Ξαντρίαι.
οὗτε, Epic form of rel. common in Aeschylus. (ὅστε Pers. 297, αἵτε Eum. 1024, ἐξ οὗτε Pers. 762, ἅτε Cho. 615, etc.)
λαγὼ δίκην, like a hare, i. e. they tore him as dogs a hare. [Scholiast's int. 'crouching like a hare' is frigid and absurd.] Notice absence of caesura; Ag. 943, Cho. 493.
Πλειστός, a small river south of Delphi: Apollonius (2.711) speaks of Korykian nymphs daughters of Pleistos.

Ποσειδώνος: there was an altar of Poseidon at Delphi. [There were various old traditions about Poseidon having once possessed Delphi and exchanged it for other places, which may be connected with his worship there.]
τέλειον, the fulfiller: so Ag. 973 Ζεῦ Ζεῦ τέλειε, τὰς ἐμὰς εὐχὰς τέλει.
Abridged, but quite intelligible, expression for 'May I find this time better response than I found in my former entrances to the shrine.'
τυχεῖν με, acc. inf. of prayer, common constr. with or without δός or δοῖεν (Cho. 307, O. C. 868, etc.). For acc. ἄριστα with τυχεῖν, cf. Ag. 1228.
πάρ', are here, for πάρεισιν, is commonly read here. But it is more natural to take παρά as a preposition; and it is quite easy to under- stand are come.
ἴτων, rare form for ἰόντων ος ἴτωσαν.
μαντεύεσθαι. is used both of prophesying and 'consulting the god,' or getting a prophecy. Here both would suit, but the former is the sense in which Aeschylus uses the word elsewhere.
ὡς ἄν, according as, indef. relat. use. [She passes into the temple, and there is a pause : then she comes out horror-stricken and half fainting.]
δεινά. is nom. λέξαι and δρακεῖν epex. inf. after the adj. Things terrible to tell of, terrible to behold have sent me back, etc.'
ὥς, Epic for ὥστε, common in Trag., esp. in Aeschylus (e.g. Ag. 358, 546, 575, 665, 1381).
σωκεῖν, ‘to be strong.'

ἀκταίνω, a unique word of which the meaning is disputed. The Schol. and old lexicons give (1) to uplift, or be uplifted. (2) to exult, ‘prance' (γαυριᾶν), ‘leap violently' (ἀτάκτως πηδᾶν). The sense however requires, not, 'I can't move violently, but rather 'I can hardly move at all:' it is best therefore to take ἀκταίνω, to lift. βάσιν, my step: this is a correction in the best MS., all the texts reading στάσιν, (which is perhaps possible, and then 'to uplift my stand- ing' would mean to stand upright;) but βάσιν is easier and far more likely.
χερσίν, ‘by aid of hands:' holding on, to support her failing limbs. [Schol. actually says she comes out on all fours, τετραποδηδόν!!]

ἀντίπαιs, rather a strange compound, the preposition ἀντί governing (so to speak) the waῖς, and not some word outside as usual.
Aeschylus is fond of these compounds : ἀντίκεντρον 136, 466, ἀντίφερνον Ag. 406, ἀντήνωρ ib. 443, ἀντίδουλος Cho. 135.
μὲν οὖν, corrective, as usual. 'Nay, she is as a child.'

The inner sanctuary of Delphi (μυχός) contained the statue of Apollo: the ὀμφαλός, see next note: the altar with the eternal fire, fed only with fir-wood; and the roof all hung with garlands (πολυστεφή). In the centre was the chasm with the tripod where the priestess sate, and inhaled the intoxicating fumes of the smoke which came up from below.

ὀμφαλός, navel, was the name given to Delphi, as the centre of the earth, and particularly (as here) to a white stone in the μυχός of the temple¹. Strabo tells us (9. 3.) that 'an ὀμφαλός bound with fillets' was shown in the temple; and Pausanias (10. 16. 3) that 'the Delphians said their ὀμφαλός, which was made of white stone, was the centre of the earth, and quoted from Pindar a passage which agreed with their ac- count.In Pausanias' time it was in the front court; but in Aeschylus' day there is evidence it was in the μυχός (Müll. Eum. 27). The ὀμφαλός as a round or oval object is often found on coins or vases or sculptures relating to Delphi.
Το μέν answers δέ 1. 46.

προστρόπαιον, lit. turning toward, hence suppliant. The supplication might be for vengeance (as Ag. 1587, Cho. 286), or more commonly for purification, as here. Hence the word contracts another meaning, guilty; see below 11. 234, 237.
Some take it here agreeing with ἄνδρα; but rhythm and order indi- cate that it goes with ἕδραν, a suppliant seat; so Soph. O. C. 1309, π. λιταί.

The olive-branch, with tufts of wool attached, was the regular sign of the suppliant : ἱκετῶν ἐριοστέπτοισι κλάδοισι Suppl. 23, κλάδοις κατάσκιον ὅμιλον ib. 354, ἱκτηρίοις κλάδοισιν ἐξεστεμμένοι Ο. Τ. 3.
σωφρόνως seems to mean duly, piously.
'For so will I plainly tell, i. e. about the suppliant there was nothing strange : the horrible and mysterious part of the sight she goes on to describe.
λόχος, ‘troop:' for the number of the Eumenides see Intro- duction.

Γοργόνας. : Aeschylus describes these in the Prometheus (899) as 'Three winged sisters with snakes for hair, loathed of men, whom no mortal shall see and live:' and the Furies are compared to them, Cho. 1047, 'In dusky robes and twined with many snakes, like Gorgons.’

If this line is right the substantive is understood: '[Monsters]
have I seen ere now in a picture, snatching the feast of Phineus,' i.e. the Harpies.

The Harpyiae are in Homer simply the 'spirits of the storm' who are said to have carried off those who disappear suddenly (e. g. Od. 1. 241). The story is told by later writers as follows: Phineus, king of Thrace, being falsely told that his sons were conspiring to corrupt their stepmother, put out their eyes. The gods in wrath blinded him, and sent loathsome monsters, the Harpies, to snatch away his banquet. The best known account is Vergil's, Aen. 3. 212.

[Herm. and others thinking the omission of the subst. too harsh, sup- pose a line lost; but it would be difficult to write one which would not separate δεῖπνον too much from Φινέως. Schol. plainly had our text.]
γε μήν, ‘yet,' adversative as usual: γε μέντοι, γε μὲν δή (and in Homer γε μέν), also used in the same way. So σπορᾶς γε μὴν ἐκ τῆσδε Ρ. V. 871, σὺν χρόνῳ γε μήν Ag. 1378.
οὐ πλατοῖσι, ‘unapproachable:' for the breath was deadly with blood and fire, and withered up what it touched (138). MSS. read πλαστοῖσι, feigned: but the other is far more forcible.
κόσμος, their garb.
i. e. 'I know not the race nor land whence this company are sprung.'

μὴ μεταστένειν πόνον, without repenting of its toil, is an elaborate repetition and explanation of ἀνατί, unharmed. [The inf. is literally the object of ἐπεύχεται : 'boasts that having reared... it does not repent,' i. e. 'boasts to rear without repenting'].

The horror and pollution of these monsters is too fearful: she will leave it to Apollo himself, who as seer (τερασκόπος) will under- stand, as 'prophet-healer' (ἰατρόμαντις) will cure, as καθάρσιος will purify.

p.stage: [The priestess retires: the scene shifts and shews the interior of the shrine: Orestes with a bloody sword seated on the ὀμφαλός, Apollo and Hermes standing by: the chorus of Furies asleep all about on stone seats or the floor.]

div.p: [64-178. SCENE I. Part 1. Apollo promises Orestes protection, and prophesies his wanderings; Hermes leads him away. Chorus rebuked by Klytaimnestra's ghost awake, lament Orestes' escape, revile Apollo, and end with threats that Orestes shall not escape.]

There is a difficulty here as to how the change of scene was exactly managed. The Schol. says, 'machines turned round shew the in- terior:' the ἐκκύκλημα or ἐξώστρα, which was generally used for displaying interiors, is described as 'a platform on high boards with a seat on it' (Pollux 4. 128) and a machine on wheels which was
turned round and displayed what was going on within' (Schol. Ar. Ach. 407). This would suffice for ordinary cases, as in Ach. 407, where Euripides is shewn in his study: or Ag. 1372, Cho. 973, where the slayer standing over the victims is seen. But here we have the whole interior: the ὀμφαλός, the seats, Orestes, Apollo, Hermes, and the whole chorus of Furies (twelve or fifteen, see Introduction): and it is difficult to see how they could all be got on to a moveable platform. There is much to be said for Müller's view (Eum. 29) that here the priestess speaks the first part of her speech, 1. 1-33, before the curtain, which is afterwards drawn down and reveals the adytum.
διὰ τέλους, idiomatic expression for ever.

If MSS. καὶ πρόσω δέ is right, it means 'and even when far away,' i. e. ' I will watch over you when near, and even when afar, and I will punish your foes.' This makes good sense and need not be altered, though καὶ πρόσω γε Blom. is possibly right.

ὕπνῳ πεσοῦσαι, ‘prostrate in sleep' [they lie] : πεσοῦσαι used rather loosely for the perfect, like θανόντes for τεθνηκότες. But the construction is rather harsh, with a strained tense and no verb: and not improbably πεσοῦσαι is corrupt for some verb. The best suggestion is Weil's πεδῶνται : (others πρέπουσι, πέλουσι : παρεῖνται Weckl.).
μίγνυται, 'consorts.” γραῖαι, παλαιαὶ παῖδες, ‘old, wrinkled maidens;' a bold and contemptuous oxymoron to express loathing.

The least alteration of MSS. is to read βιβῶντ᾽ ἀν᾿ ἀεὶ τὴν π. χ., ever pacing the travelled earth. This involves the displacement of the preposition ἀνά by ἀεί, a very rare and harsh licence: H. P. quote Plato σὺν ἀεί τινι βίᾳ, but ἀεί τινι is far less harsh an interruption than ἀεί alone. [This we shall see if we try it in English, 'rule with always some violence,' is less impossible than 'walk over always the earth.'] A better example is Laws 797 D ἐν ὡς ἔπος εἰπεῖν οὐ τοῖς μὲν τοῖς δ᾽ οὐ.

The conjectures are very numerousἀνατεί Turn., ἀvíᾳ Fritzsche, ἐῶντα δ' ἀεί Weil, ἀνοίᾳ Wies., ἀν᾿ ἄστη Don., and others worse. but do not convince : ἀνάγκῃ Musgr. is perhaps the best: or to read περῶντα δ᾽ ἀεί with Weil and Weckl. I leave the ἀν' ἀεί, as it is perhaps barely possible.
The Homeric βιβῶντ' (used also by Pindar) is a better correction than βεβῶτ', as nearer the MSS. and more likely to have been corrupted.
Notice περιρρύτας, fem. form from compd. adj. So περικλυστά Pers. 596, εὐφιλητάν Theb. 108, δυσοιστά (?) Eum. 789, παναρκέτας (?) Cho. 69.
βουκολούμενος. (mid. as Schol. interprets), tending, i. e. brooding over; a bold metaphor characteristic of the poet.
ἄγκαθεν, in thy arms, from ἄγκη, ‘the bent arm:' like the Homeric ἀγκὰς ἑλεῖν or ἔχειν, to take in the arms: cf. Ag. 3.
θελκτηρίους, ‘persuasive,' to the judges of the Areiopagos.

'Learn also to take heed, though to our ears it sounds too bold to be said to a god, is not so meant in the Greek, nor does Apollo so take it: it is simply 'forget me not, O god.' Notice ἐπίστᾳ contracted for ἐπίστασαι; so we find δύνᾳ.
Thy strength is warrant thou wilt aid me; taking eὖ ποιεῖν together.
κάρτα δ᾽ ὧν ἐπώνυμος, true to thy name, give guidance : the title πομπαῖος meaning the guider.

Zeus reveres this sanctity of outlaws, which comes to men from the fortune of fair escort; a rather obscure expression, but ex- plained by the context: Zeus reveres the claim which outlaws have (on the pity of men), a claim which springs from the (divine) power which guides them: i. e. ‘Orestes, though an outlaw, will find pity since thou wilt guide him. [Wecklein reads τὸ κηρύκων (for τόδ᾽ ἐκ.), of Hermes: certainly much simpler, though perhaps unnecessary.]
[Apollo retires; Hermes leads Orestes out ; the stage is empty. Then from below the ghost of Klytaimnestra rises.]
This sentence is written with an effective vehemence which is very dramatic: the broken and rough grammar being exactly imitative of strongly excited speech.

The drift is: 'I, thus dishonoured by you [the negligent Furies], among the dead below am constantly reproached for my deeds-wander- ing in disgrace and blamed by all-but for my sufferings no god takes heed.'

Thus the antithesis to ὧν μὲν ἔκτανον is really παθοῦσα δ᾽ (100) and αἰσχρῶς δ᾽ ἀλῶμαι answers οὐκ ἐκλείπεται. Note the double break of construction: (1) the intrusion of οὐκ ἐκλείπεται with a new subject between ἐγώ and ἀλῶμαι : (2) the entire anacoluthon παθοῦσα δ᾽ with- out verb followed by οὐδεὶς μηνίεται. For the latter compare Ag. 1008 ὅκνος βαλὼν ... οὐκ ἔδυ δόμος, Cho. 521 πάντα ἐκχέας . . . μάτην ὁ μόχθος, and Eur. Cycl. 331, Hipp. 24, Iph. Taur. 947, etc. See 478.
πρός, common poetic use for ὑπό of agent: Cho. 133, 346, etc. So ἐκ, παρά, and ἀπό are poetically used. So below 1. 102.

The MSS. read ὅρα δὲ πληγὰς τάσδε καρδίᾳ σέθεν, ‘behold
these wounds with thy heart, the use of καρδίᾳ being at first sight supported by what follows for the mind sees in sleep.' But Aeschylus al- ways uses καρδία (as we do ‘heart') of emotion not of intelligence : ‘grief,’ anxiety, care, fear, wrath, courage, favour, desire-never of perception. So I take Canter's καρδίας ὅθεν adopted by Dind. Pal. Herm. Paley is further no doubt right in reading ὁρᾶτε: the plural is wanted: the asyndeton improves the sense, being more passionate: and the singular clearly arose from σέθεν.
Behold these wounds in my heart, from whence they came; a fierce reminder of their duty to hunt Orestes, and a far finer sense than the MSS. reading.
ὄμμασιν λαμπρύνεται, stately Aeschylean for 'is clear- sighted.'

μοῖρ᾽ ἀπρόσκοπος βροτῶν, 'tis the lot of mortals to be blind. Others take it the lot of men cannot be foretold: but the sense of the other is better, the antithesis is more pointed, ('seeing in sleep, blind in the day,') and ἀπρόσκοπος is more naturally active. [The Schol. says ἡ τῆς φρενὸς μοῖρα, whence H. and others read φρενῶν for βροτῶν : but the Schol. is only (rather stupidly) explaining μοῖρα in connection with the φρήν of the last line: it proves nothing about the reading: φρήν and φρενῶν would be very flat repetition.]
Wineless libations, sober cheer: poetic amplification. The Ερινύες had no wine in their offerings: νήφων ἀοίνοις Ο. C. 100, μηδὲ προσφέρειν μέθυ ib. 481. So again l. 860 ἀοίνοις θυμώμασι.

ὥραν, the acc. is best explained as a kind of loose apposition to νυκτίσεμνα δείπνα: the apposition really being to the part of the expression which contains the notion of night. The Erinyes alone had midnight sacrifices.

καὶ ταῦτα, usually with participle: here loosely but naturally with principal verb. The fact is, the ὤρουσεν is grammatically needless ('he is gone like a fawn, and that too from the very midst of the snare'), but is redundantly added, picking up and further emphasizing οἴχεται.

ἐγκατιλλώψας, a strange word, which occurs again Aesch. Sisyph. (Frag. 211) meaning mock. We find also κατιλλώπτω, ἐνιλλώπτω: the derivation seems to be ἴλλω, twist, ὀπ-, face:' hence to leer, to sneer, and so to scoff.
τῆς ἐμῆς περὶ ψυχῆς, ‘for dear life;' a proverbial expression as in English (rather strange in the mouth of a ghost), meaning that the issue is of the last importance to her.

ὄναρ, might be nom., I, a dream, like Ag. 82 ὄναρ ἡμερόφαντον ἀλαίνει (so Schütz, Wakef. H. Pal.). But it is rather more naturally taken acc. in a dream, as l. 131. II
[The Furies begin to groan and mutter and move uneasily in their sleep.]

The MSS. read φίλοις γάρ εἰσιν οὐκ ἐμοῖς προσίκτορες, which makes no sense, since it could only be translated for there are pro- tectors for friends who are not mine, an obscure and impossible expression for my enemies have gods to help them. Herm.'s cor- rection οὐκ ἐμοί is neat and simple: 'my friends have helpers: I have none:' and P. D. adopt it.

But it is not really satisfactory : φίλοις without article or possessive is very harsh, and even the use of the word at all is unnatural (not at all like line 108): and προσίκτωρ, though supported by Ζεὺς ἀφίκτωρ (Supp. 1), is suspicious.
I prefer on the whole Weil's φίλοι γάρ εἰσιν, οὐκ ἐμοῖς προσεικότες ‘for he has friends, not like to mine,' an effective taunt simply expressed.
Notice the ironic elaborate plainness of this line, as of an angry person who cannot make herself understood.

If we keep the MSS. πέπρακται, we can only construe (with Paley) this line 'What hast thou accomplished save to work me harm?' i. e. 'you are appointed to avenge me, and by negligence you have only done harm, in letting Orestes escape.'

The Schol. however paraphrases τί μέλλεις τὸ σὸν ἔργον ἀνύειν (‘why delay to do your duty?'), clearly understanding the text 'what business is yours save to do harm (to Orestes)?' Herm. followed by Weil tries to get this sense out of πέπρακται, quid tibi agitur: but the tense makes it impossible. If we accept the meaning of the Schol. we must read with Bentley [Stanl. Butl. Hart.] πέπρωται or with Wakef. τέτακται. I have taken πέπρωται. The scornful summons What is your business but mischief?' is more characteristic of Klytaimnestra and more effective than a complaint.

κύριοι ξυνωμόται, fit conspirators: a bold and characteristic image. κύριος means rightful: sleep and weariness naturally act together. For the figure cp. Ag. 650 ξυνώμοσαν γάρ, ὄντες ἔχθιστοι τὸ πρὶν Πῦρ καὶ θάλασσα.

[Mutterings redoubled and louder] 'Seize him, seize him ... give heed!' The muttering and restless movements and slow awakening with fierce cries are finely dramatic: Aeschylus is unmatched in producing these effects of suspense and terror. Müller ingeniously suggests that it should be read φράζου, followed by λαβέ seven times repeated, as φράζου, mark him, more naturally comes first: the iambic metrical system is preserved: and the leader would then say φράζου, and each of the seven pairs λαβέ. We have however (see p. 23) preferred the view that the chorus was 12, not 15.]
The dreams of animals are noticed by Theocr. (21.44), Lucret. (4. 989), and Aristotle (Hist. An. 4. 10).
μηδ᾽ ἀγνοήσῃς πῆμα, ‘forget not my wrong.'
ἀντίκεντρα, like spurs; see 1. 38.
τῷ, on him. Epic use of article as demonstr. frequent in Aeschylus: see 11. 174, 340, 462, 484.

Notice the powerful and imaginative phrasing, waft a bloody breath, shrivel with vapour, wither with pursuit. [The ghost of Klytaimnestra disappears below ; the Chorus gradually awake, the leader rousing the others.]
Let us see if this prelude is vain, rather obscure, but φροίμιον τύδε most naturally refers to the song they are going to sing, a song of lament at the escape, and chiding and reproach to Apollo.
ἰδέσθαι, the middle, is an Epic use, common in Tragg. Note the loose but natural grammar κἀπολακτίσασ᾽ (sing.), ἰδώμεθ᾽ (plur.). So exactly Aristoph. Aves 203, ἐμβὰς ἐς τὴν λόχμην καλοῦμεν. ...

This line is out of agreement; and generally the character of the first stanzas is that the lines are very disjointed: the true explanation being no doubt that the song is alternately taken up by one and another of the Furies, to give the dramatic effect of their excitement and anger. So the Schol. says κομματικῶς ἕκαστον κατ᾿ ἰδίαν προφερετέον· 'each bit must be delivered separately by a single voice.' It is not worth while to attempt (as Herm. does) to distribute the parts exactly, as there is no evidence.
ὁ θήρ, ‘our prey.'

νέος γραίας, simply young and old. This complaint that Apollo as one of the younger race has overridden the Furies who are elder goddesses constantly recurs through the play, 163, 731, 778, 838, 845; see Introduction. καθιππάζομαι, a bold picturesque word for trample down, so 731, 779.
τοκεῦσιν, generalising plural, to his mother, as the sense requires.
τῶνδε, your acts, insulting the old goddesses, and protecting the impious suppliant.
μεσολαβεῖ, another tersely vivid word: the goad 'grasped by the middle' to give the blow force.
'Tis come, I feel it, the sore, sore chill of the cruel scourger's blow. δάμιος μαστίκτωρ is the public scourger: a bold image for Klytaimnestra's taunts.

The MSS. read-
κρατοῦντες τὸ πᾶν δίκας πλέον·
φονολιβή θρόνον
περὶ πόδα, περὶ κάρα[MSS. φονολειβῆ, clearly an error]
πάρεστι γᾶς ὀμφαλόν κ.τ.λ.
This stopping must be wrong, as the construction is very clumsy with θρόνον in apposition to ὀμφαλόν, and the strophe which is very parallel in sound and structure makes it practically certain that the stop is at κάρα. We then have two alternatives : (1) Το keep θρόνον, changing stop from πλέον to κάρα :
Ruling utterly beyond the right
A throne dripping blood
From feet to head:
We may see the Earth's navel, etc.
[φονολιβή θρόνον is a regular dochmiac, and may rightly correspond to μεσολαβεῖ κέντρῳ, where the long kev- is an irrational syllable. So for example O. Τ. 1315 δύσοῦρῖστὸν ōv corresponds to 1323 τυφλὸν κῆδεῦῶν.
Even if syllabic correspondence were required, we might easily correct to θρᾶνον Ahrens, θᾶκον Rauchenstein: but there is no need].

(2) To read with Herm. and others after Wakefield θρόμβον, and suppose the second and third lines interjectory, by another speaker: κρατοῦντες intransitive:
Ruling utterly beyond the right:-
A blood-dripping clot
Around his feet, about his head-
We may see, etc.
The two lines would then be a vivid and bold picture of angry horror at the foul stain on the god's shrine: 'such are the doings of the young gods' as the ancient Furies dramatically exclaim. On the whole I prefer (1) which keeps the MS. reading, certainly also read (though misunderstood) by the Schol. who says, τὸν θρόνον οὗ Ορέστης καθῆτο πάρεστιν ὁρᾶν φονολειβῆ. It was not the seat of Orestes but the seat of Apollo.
ἀρόμενον, ‘that has taken upon it ;' βλοσυρὸν ἄγος αἱμάτων, a fell pollution of blood. For ὀμφαλόν see line 40.
μάντις ὤν, i. e. ‘though a seer,' and thus the last who should have allowed pollution.

αὐτόσσυτος, αὐτόκλητος, at thine own bidding, at thine own summons: the repetition of similar words is noticeable all through this chorus; a rhetorical turn due to the strength of their wrath and passion. So περὶ πόδα, περὶ κάρα - βαρὺ περίβαρυ - δαΐου δαμίου, etc.

And crushing the ancient Fates. The Schol. followed by
Pal. and others, understands this of themselves, the Furies being identified for the moment with the Fates. So Eurip. Elect. 1252 says of Orestes-
δειναὶ δὲ Κῆρές σ' αἱ κυνώπιδες θεαὶ
τροχηλατήσουσ᾽ ἐμμανῆ πλανώμενον.
But it is very difficult to believe that Aeschylus who makes the Furies call upon the Fates (961) as 'our own sisters, righteous goddesses,' and speak of them as apart from themselves (724), should here put one for the other. It is better to consider (with Dind. Linw. Weil) that the allusion is here, as more fully explained below (724), to Apollo having allowed the Fates to be robbed by the rescue of Alkestis from death. This explains the κάμοί γε next line, 'To us too' the Furies, as well as to the Fates; and also 1. 175 'He if he fly beneath the earth shall never be set free,' as Alkestis was set free by Herakles who wrestled with death and recovered her.
It remains however an unusually obscure allusion, and hence one cannot feel confident.
τόν, Orestes: for Epic form cp. 137, 357.

MSS. read μιάστορ᾽ ἐκείνου πάσεται : corrupt, neither metre nor sense. The Schol. say, 'Being defiled he shall receive on his head another avenger, and his descendants shall pay us the penalty.' The words italicised clearly point to some correction like ἐγγενῆ or ἐν γένει (Hart.) or ἐκ γένους (Weil). I have taken the former, 'being guilty of blood he shall find, smiting his head, another avenger of his kindred: i. e. the blood feud shall be continued: Klytaimnestra smote Agamemnon: Orestes smote Klytaimnestra; another shall strike him and the feud be carried on.
μιάστωρ, properly one who pollutes, used for 'an avenger' Soph. El. 603 (of Orestes), Eur. Med. 1371.

p.stage: [Enter from the inner shrine Apollo, who sternly addresses the Furies.]

div.p: [SCENE I, Part 2. Apollo orders Furies to depart: they plead with him, that he is sheltering the guilty. He replies that Klytaimnestra was also guilty. The Chorus defy him, and threaten Orestes. Apollo promises to aid him.]
A winged glancing snake, a bold and splendid image for an arrow.
The black foam sucked from men, is explained in the next line.

καρανιστῆρες ὀφθαλμώρυχοι δίκαι, dooms that shear off the head and tear out the eyes. The horror is intensified both by
the extraordinary weight and force of the lines, and by the abstract: the Furies are banished to a land of ghastly things. For the masc. form καρανιστήρ with fem. word δίκη compare σωτήρ τύχη Ag. 664, λαμπὰς πορευτής ib. 287, θέλκτωρ πειθώ Suppl. 1040, παραγιγνόμεναι πράκτορες below 319, βρωτῆρας αἰχμάς 803.

A corrupt and difficult line: MSS. read-
... σπέρματός τ᾽ ἀποφθοραὶ
παίδων κακοῦται χλοῦνις ἠδ᾽ ἀκρωνία.
The explanation turns on the meaning of χλοῦνις. (1) One of the Schol. understands it to mean castration: and this is supported by Aristotle (Hist. An. 6. 28), who says distinctly τῶν δὲ ἀρρένων καὶ ἀγρίων οἱ τομίαι μείζους γίγνονται καὶ χαλεπώτεροι, ὥσπερ καὶ Ὅμηρος ἐποίησεν (11. 9. 539), Τρέψεν ἔπι χλούνην σῦν ἄγριον : which proves that Arist. took χλούνης=τομίας: ΕEustathius (772), who quotes the authority of Aeschylus, Aelian, and Aristotle for this int.: and Aeschylus himself, who (Frag. 62) has χλούνης apparently meaning eunuch; but (2) others reply that Homer cannot have meant a σûς τομίας but the opposite : and hence χλοῦνις = virility. These retain κακοῦται and read ἀποφθορᾷ, translating 'and by the destruction of the seed the virility of boys is ruined.' So Dind. Pal. Weil.

In favour of (1) is the very strong evidence of Aristotle, backed by Schol. and Eustathius, and further the run of the lines, which consists of a heap of abstract nouns which would be very harshly broken by a finished sentence. We must therefore assume κακοῦται corrupt: though no satisfactory emendation has been suggested. We may add that those who support (2) assume that Aeschylus must have used the word in the Homeric sense: but it is quite possible that he may have misused an old word, and made the same mistake as Aristotle: and the evidence of Frag. 62 confirms this.
μύζουσιν οἰκτισμὸν πολύν, ‘make sore and piteous moaning,' a terribly graphic expression for the slow torture of impalement.
ἑορτῆς. depends on στέργηθρα: what manner of feast it is ye love, loathed of the gods [lit. what... loving, ye are loathed ...].
ὑφηγεῖται, lit. leads to it: i. e. shews it.

πλησίοισι, ‘close at hand,' seems rather a feeble word and is perhaps corrupt: though none of the suggestions (πλουσίοισι Pauw., πανθύτοισι Mein., Πυθίοισι Mart., and many others worse) are con- vincing: Πυθίοισι perhaps the best.
τρίβεσθαι μύσος, rub off their foul pollution, a forcible and contemptuous phrase.
Observe the fine sudden figure, after his manner: Begone, ye flock without a shepherd: no god loves such a herd.

MSS. read εἰς τὸ πᾶν, the copyists having fallen into the
common Aeschylean phrase, here very flat and inappropriate: Canter's εἷς τὸ πᾶν makes it at once forcible and right.
τοσοῦτο, i. e. as to explain.

Note the idiomatic use of ὥστε instead of simple acc. and infin. So Thuc. 1. 119 δεηθέντες ὥστε ψηφίσασθαι, 5. 17 ψηφισαμένων ὥστε καταλύεσθαι, Eur. Hipp. 1327 ἤθελ᾽ ὥστε γίγνεσθαι, Soph. Phil. 656 ἆρ᾽ ἔστιν ὥστε . . . λαβεῖν.

πρᾶξαι, to exact, plainly the right word here: MSS. read πέμψαι, ‘to send, which is explained as meaning to Agamemnon: but that would surely require τῷ πατρί. τί μήν; lit. 'what then?' i. e. 'why not?' So, e. g. Plat. Theaet. 145 ἢ οὐχ ἅπερ οἱ ἐπιστήμονες ταῦτα καὶ σοφοί ; (answer) τί μήν;
To welcome blood new-shed is a bold and vivid phrase for 'received the murderer red-handed.'
Certainly to be written a question.
κόμπασον γέρας καλόν, ironical: 'go boast thy glorious office!'

ἥτις νοσφίσῃ, a woman who slays: the subjunctive inde- finite, because, as frequently, the special case is (rhetorically) put in general terms. The absence of av is Epic usage, common in Trag. and found even in Attic prose, οὗ βραχεῖς ἀρκῶσι Thuc. 4. 17, οἵτινες νομίσωσι 4. 18, ᾧ μὴ ᾖ Plat. Phaedr. 247 B.

αὐθέντης φόνος, ‘the murder of a kinsman; ' the most fearful pollution according to the Greek view: so much so that a sharp dis- tinction was drawn (as here) between the murder of a husband (not an ὅμαιμος) and the murder of a mother.

I take the best suggestion, εἰργάσω (Wordsw.), out of many¹ for the corrupt MSS. reading ᾐρκέσω. It must be some word with simple meaning, like 'thou hast made despised and dishonoured' (lit. 'of no value'), to suit both ἄτιμα and παρ᾽ οὐδέν.
The Marriage of Zeus and Hera was the ἱερὸς γάμος, the sacred or ideal marriage: and "Hpa was called Τελεία, 'the Accom- plisher,' as marriage was a τέλος or accomplished rite.

For marriage ordained by Fate for man and woman is stronger than an Oath, and guarded by Justice. These fine lines containing an ideal of marriage as an indissoluble bond under the highest sanctions seem in advance of ordinary Greek thought and feeling on the subject; but we must remember that Aeschylus belongs to the older school, and one of the charges against the younger poets was that they lowered the ideal of marriage: and further that the immense care of the Athenian 1 ἧκέ σοι Η., ἤρκεσεν Musgr. Weil., ἡρμόσω Merk., ᾐδέσω Well., Hart. ἀρκέσει Bothe; these are the better ones. B
law for legitimacy, and the excessive seclusion of women, point in the same direction. [Weck. reads κτείνουσι συλλέκτρους: ingenious.]

MSS. read τὸ μὴ γενέσθαι, which must be wrong. The neatest emendation is Meineke's (adopted by Hart. Weil. Dind.) τίνεσθαι, ‘to punish,' which I have taken. The word is usually employed of the in- jured man punishing the wrong-doer, and means properly 'to get payment' (middle): but it is not a great stretch to use it of the Furies who are personally interested in the penalty, and may be said 'to get payment.' Of the other numerous corrections only Wakefield's μέλεσθαι need be mentioned. ἐποπτεύειν, ‘look down on them:' the proper word for a god's visi- tation or guidance : καί σ᾽ ἐποπτεύων θεός Cho. 1063, θεοὺς ἄνωθεν γῆς ἐποπτεύειν ἄχη Ag. 1579, πατρῷ᾽ ἐποπτεύων κράτη Cho. 1, etc.
ἐνθυμουμένην, ‘taking to heart.'
πράσσουσαν ἡσυχαιτέραν, ' more remiss in act, the adj. by a common poetic variation for adv. with verb. Somewhat similarly in prose σχολαῖος, χρόνιος, ἄσμενος, etc., are used adverbially.

δίκας ἐποπτεύσει, shall watch the pleadings, i. e. direct the trial.' δίκαι plural is usually pleas of right, not vengeance. So δίκας κλύοντες Ag. 813, 'hearing the cause : ' κραίνετε δίκας Cho. 462, ὑστάτας δίκας Suppl. 230, the last trial.

δ᾽ οὖν, ‘well then,' impatient and contemptuous. So Prom. 935 ὁ δ᾽ οὖν ποιείτω. τίθου (‘put or make for yourself,' middle), get. πλέω must be read for MSS. πλέον. In Ag. 1299 we have the op- posite blunder of the copyist, χρόνῳ πλέω for χρόνον πλέω: mistakes constantly arising from terminations being erroneously assimilated.
The Chorus understand Apollo to threaten, and they proudly defend their privileges.
ὥστε, 202.
No need to alter πάρ into παρά (Porson): both the rhythm and the Epic use are like Aeschylus.

δίκας μέτειμι τόνδε, i.e. I will sue for justice on him; δίκας being a rather strange sort of internal acc., the δίκαι or pleadings shewing the nature of the pursuit; see line 224. The phrase implies. that the Eumenides are going to submit to a trial: δίκην μέτειμι τόνδε would mean simply I will visit vengeance on his head. μέτειμι and μετελθεῖν are used with three kinds of accusatives, the trial or vengeance, the crime, and the criminal. Here we have trial and criminal: μετῆλθόν σ᾽ αἷμα Eur. Or. 423 (crime and criminal): so ἁρπαγὰς μετήλθετ᾽ Ἰλίου πόλιν Eur. Cycl. 280: Ag. 1666 (criminal only), Cho. 996 (crime only). *

εἰ προδῶ, Epic use of eἰ with subj. So εἰ κρανθῇ πρᾶγμα Suppl. 91, μηδ᾽ εἰ στράτευμα πλεῖον ᾖ Pers. 791, εἰ μὴ τοῖον τύχῃ Supp. 400. [Apollo retires : and the Chorus leave the stage. Then the scene is changed to Athens: the temple of Athena Polias on the Acropolis: Orestes enters and kneels as a suppliant before the statue of Athena in the front.] This change of scene, being from one temple to another, would only require the alteration of the side scenes or περίακτοι. These were pris- matic or three-sided scenes which were turned round to exhibit different surroundings: rather a primitive device. The altar and temple would remain; only the statues would have to be changed (242). [235-243. SCENE II, Part 1. Orestes prays for protection.]

προστρόπαιον, guilty here: see note on 1. 41. ἀφοίβαντον, ‘uncleansed,' from φοῖβος, bright (of course here with reference to the god). (Theocr. uses φοιβάω, to cleanse, later writers φοιβάζω : and φοιβαίνω is found in lexicographers.)

Orestes by a bold figure is said to be 'blunted and worn away,' when what the poet really means is that the guilt is blunted and worn. In English we must say so. πρός, the light ending, where the sentence is broken in the most closely bound phrase, is rare in Aeschylus, though common enough in Sophocles : e.g. ἢ κατεῖχε τὸν | νέκυν: ἐὰν δέ τοι | ληφθῇ : τὸ γὰρ | πρᾶγμ᾽ οὔτ᾽ ἔδρασα: εἰ δὲ ταῦτα μὴ | φανεῖτε: παίσαντές τε καὶ | πληγέντες : all from Antigone. But there is no reason to suspect it.

The sentence begins very abruptly without connecting particle, so that many suspect corruption, and some (Prien. Pal.) attempt to cure it by reading 1. 238 ἀλλ᾿ ἀμβλὺς ἤδη, προστετριμμένος τε and destroying stop at βροτῶν. Others make other alterations. But the antithesis οὐ προστροπαῖον . . . ἀλλ᾽ ἀμβλύς is very harsh: and the sentence inordinately long. The abruptness of ὅμοια χέρσον κ.τ.λ. does not seem impossible in the worn-out wanderer passionately seeking sanctuary. We have it again 1. 242.
[Orestes sinks down clasping the base of the statue. Enter the Chorus hunting the trail.]

[PARODOS. Chorus: Where can he be? we have searched land and sea: I scent the trail-Lo there is he clasping the image, hoping Athena's help! No! we shall suck his blood and drag him down, as he deserves.]

The voiceless informer is of course the blood, which mysteriously continues to drop wherever he goes. The Scholiast, not a
highly poetical person, remarks on the 'tragic improbability' of blood yet dropping from the sword of a man who had come from Argos to Delphi and from Delphi to Athens.
φυσιᾷ σπλάγχνον, my heart gasps, loaded and emphatic diction. ἀνδροκμῆσιν has nothing to do with Orestes (as H. Mors.): it is simply, as Schol. understands it, right wearisome.
ἀπτέροις. : the Eumenides were not winged, 1. 51.
προσγελᾷ, delights : the bold figure not Aeschylean specially, but belonging to the Greek idiom : so σὲ τὰ φυτὰ προσγελάσεται Ar. Pax 600. It is exactly the Lat. adrideo.
ἀτίτας, unpunished: lit. unpaying (act.) as Aeschylus always uses τίνω of the culprit who pays penalty. [The word seems used in pass. sense Ag, 72.]

[There is no antistrophe to guide us here, and there are several minor variations of the MSS.: the metre, however, seems mainly dochmiac, and I have taken Hermann's emendations, which are the simplest: see crit. notes.]
πλεχθείς, ‘twined,' a strong word, describing Orestes' despair- ing clasp of the image.

The difficulty here is removed if we see that the emphasis (as so often in Greek) is on the participles.
The Chorus just catch sight of him and cry:
But he again with sure defence,
And clasping the image of the immortal goddess,
Would fain take his trial for the deeds of his hands...
i. e. 'Here he is! see, clasping the statue, and hoping to be tried under the goddess' protection; but it may not be, etc.' The trial is the necessary way to safety, and the Furies try to prevent it.

[Schol. has a strange note, ἀνθ᾽ ὧν ἡμῖν χρεωστεί προσφὸξ θέλει γενέσθαι τῆς θεοῦ, for what he owes to us he wishes to become suppliant of the goddess, which looks as if he read χρεῶν, to answer for his debts, and so Scaliger reads (followed by H. Linw. Hart. Weil. Wakef.). But χερῶν is a finer expression, and we may take the Medicean MS. against an inference from an obscure and prosaic note.]

This is best taken as two sentences (with M.), the idea being repeated, as commonly in all poetry, in two forms. The sense and language are then very fine :
It may not be a mother's blood upon the earth
None can restore: alas!
The drops once shed upon the ground are lost!
The sentiment may be called the keynote of the three dramas; it is true of Iphigeneia τὸ δ᾽ ἐπὶ γᾶν πεσὸν ἅπαξ θανάσιμον ... μέλαν αἷμα τίς ἂν
πάλιν ἀγκαλέσαιτ᾽ ἐπαείδων; (Ag. 1019), and is the real basis of all the forebodings in the midst of the king's triumphal return: it is true of Agamemnon, τί γὰρ λύτρον πεσόντος αἵματος πέδοι; (Cho. 48), and νόμος ...φονίας σταγόνας χυμένας ἐς γᾶν ἄλλο προσαιτεῖν αἷμα (ib. 400), and there it is the ground of the confident hope of vengeance; and it is true here of Orestes. See again below 1. 647.
Notice Epic syncope δυσαγκόμιστον for δυσανάκομ- : the poetic use χαμαί for χαμαὶ ὄν, and Epic passive form χύμενος, cf. Cho. 401.
ῥοφεῖν, epexegetic for us to drink.
Generally read μελέων : better μελῶν, as an iambus is wanted for metre.

I take the best correction, the nearest to the MSS. and the best sense, ἀντιποίν᾽ ὡς τίνῃς ματροφόνου δύας, that thou may'st pay the full penalty for thy murdered mother's woe: the adj. ματροφόνου used with poetic elasticity, which is particularly noticeable in these compound adjectives.

τιν᾿. ἀσεβῶν is perhaps incomplete, as coming between two dochmiacs it probably should be one itself. The neatest suggestion for completing it is Hermann's τιν᾿ οὐκ εὐσεβῶν. But in the uncertainty of the metre I have left the reading as the MSS. have it, especially as τιν' ἀσεβῶν is a resolved cretic, and we have cretics introduced l. 262, and l.266.

For Hades under the earth is a mighty controller of men, and watches all with his recording heart.' This conception of the Justice and Moral supremacy of the powers below is very fine, and noticeable as being rather unusual. The Powers below are often spoken of as terrible, and unforgetting, and so forth; but here the tone is higher. See Introduction.

[SCENE II, Part 2. Orestes calls on Athena, claiming to be now purified, to help him wheresoe'er she be. The Chorus reply defiantly that neither Apollo nor Athena will help, and sing the binding song.]
καὶ λέγειν, i. e. and I know where it is right to speak. The double construction of ἐπίσταμαι is perhaps a little harsh, but there is no reason to suspect it.

The Schol. tells us that an ἐναγής (or person under a curse) might not go near anyone or look at or speak to him till purified. So Aeschylus himself below 1. 448. But the purification is complete 1. 445; and he has been ordered by the god 1. 279; and therefore he may speak 1. 287.
In the fine figurative style of Aeschylus the blood-stain slumbers and withers.
i. e. it would be long to tell from the beginning. ἐξ ἀρχῆς is by a slight stretch of usage, used closely with λόγος, equivalent to τὸ ἐξ ἀρχῆς λέγειν.
ἀβλαβεῖ, harmless; proving that he was purified.

I agree with Musgr. Herm. Hart. Dind. Weil. etc., that this line is spurious. It is clearly a proverbial line about the destructiveness of time; and even if we alter καθαιρεῖ τo καθαίρει with Stanl. Pal. etc. Aeschylus could not have said (1. 283) that Orestes was cleansed by sacrifice, and then abruptly (1. 286), Time cleanses all.
αὐτόν, myself: the 'me' is not wanted after emphatic ἐμοί
The reference to the treaty formed 459 B. C. (the year before the play) between Athens and Argos against Sparta is obvious. See Intro- duction.
Τρίτων was in the stories of Athena a Libyan lake from which she was supposed to have sprung; afterwards identified with the large salt lake in the south of Tunis.
The story very likely arose out of the obscure Homeric epithet for Athena, Τριτογένεια, which perhaps meant born of the water, and anyhow was not clearly understood by the later Greeks.

Whether with upright step or covered foot: whether stand- ing as in the ordinary statues or covering her feet, i.e. sitting. Pal. quotes Strabo (13. 1) as saying ' In many of the ancient images of Athena she is represented as sitting.'
This seems the best interpretation of an obscure passage.

Weil suggests the allusion is to the Athenian war in Egypt, in sup- port of the Libyan chieftain Inaros, who had rebelled against Persia; a large Athenian fleet was sent out in 460, two years before this play. This explains φίλοις ἀρήγουσ᾽.

The Phlegraean plain is the narrow promontory of Pallene in Chalkidike, north east of Greece. The story was that the gods here fought the giants; a story as old as Pindar (Nem. 1. 100), in which fight we gather that the warrior goddess Athena marshalled the hosts.
The name 'Phlegraean plain' was afterwards given to the volcanic coast of Campania, which some strangely have supposed to be meant here.
γένοιτο, regular sequence after ἔλθοι. In English we say May she come, and therefore naturally have the primary sequence, that she may prove.
ὅπου φρενῶν, where in the heart it lies.
A bloodless victim' she calls Orestes, consistently with the threat (11. 264 and 267), I will drain thee dry and carry thee below.
δαιμόνων is the powers below, i, e. both the Furies who will drink his blood and Hades (1. 274) who ordains and directs the vengeance.
σκιάν, a shadow, not a ghost, for he was to be carried off below yet living (1. 267): but all the vigour sucked out of him with his blood. [Schol. reads σκιά with MSS., and takes it voc. Unlikely.]

[FIRST STASIMON. 'We are just and only pursue the guilty. Mother Night, hear! Apollo wrongs us (307-333). Fate bids us pursue the wicked, even after death (334-346). We are dark powers: apart from the gods: our lot is to ruin wicked houses (347-359). We relieve the gods of this: and chase and catch even the swift. The proud are brought low: they know not till the woe comes (360-380). We are unforgetful, implacable, terrible; men must fear and honour us, though we be Powers of Darkness' (381-396).]

Orestes maintains a patient and scornful silence: which rouses the Chorus to still greater fury. There would be a dramatic pause before this line; then the furious threat 1. 305. There is no need to divide the speech between different speakers, as Hartung, Paley, and others, following M. G.
ὕμνον δέσμιον σέθεν, the song that binds thee, the choric song acting as an infernal spell to make Orestes their prey: and perhaps accompanied by mysterious binding gestures.
δεδόκηκεν, 'tis our resolve, poetic form for regular δέδοκται.
λάχη might be the office of the Furies, as Cho. 360: but with ἐπινωμᾷ it makes better sense to refer it to ἀνθρώπους. How our troop assigns the lots of men.
στάσις, as Choeph. 114, 458.
I take Hermann's original correction προνέμοντα, that puts forth for all to see: opposed to the action of the guilty man who 'hides' (l. 317) his bloody hands.
I take Hermann's corr. εὐθυδίκαιοι (justified by ὀρθοδίκαιοι 1. 994) and H. L. Ahrens' οἰόμεθ'.
πράκτορες, avengers, from πράσσειν in the special sense 'to exact a debt.' So τὸν πατρὸς φόνον πράξαντα 1. 624, χερὶ πράκτορι Ag. 111. For the masc. form πράκτωρ with fem. substantive cf. line 186.
τελέως, unfailingly: it goes with παραγιγ. πρακ. and ex- presses the persistent and complete vengeance.
ἀλαοῖσι καὶ δεδορκόσιν, the sightless and the seeing, i. e. the dead and the living. So δερκομένοισι καὶ δυσομμάτοις 1. 388.

ματρῷον ἅγνισμα κύριον φόνου, rightful atonement for a mother's blood ματρῷον poetically transferred from φόνου to ἄγνισμα, as the thought comes naturally in that order 'expiation for a mother for her blood.' ...

In the refrain note the effect of the accumulated adjectives and nouns describing the charm :
Over the victim this is our song-
A frenzy, a maddening distraction, -
A chant of the Furies
Untuned to the lyre, a spell to chain the soul,
blighting the life of man.
αὐονά is also found (Simon. Iamb. vii. 20) in the sense of cry, [from root αϝ, shout] and it may be so taken here by joining it with ἀφόρμικτος, a cry unmusical to men: but the other sense from αὐαίνω, to wither or waste, is more forcible, and so the Schol. Med. takes it: ὁ ξηραίνων τοὺς βροτούς.
διανταία, piercing, deadly, a favourite word of Aeschylus, usually of wounding: δ. πεπλαγμένους [πλαγάν] Theb. 894, δ. βέλει Cho. 184, and again δ. οὐτῷ ib. 640.
This is far more Aeschylean and forcible than the common rendering all pervading (Lin. Pal. Hart. Mors. etc., following Schol.).

Taking the old corrections of the corrupt text, which are much the simplest and best, we get a good sense:
To those mortals who light upon sinful deeds of blood,
To cling to them, until
He [the guilty man] pass beneath the earth:
And [even] in death he is not over-free.
ξυμπέσωσιν is suspected by some edd.: why, they ask, should Furies pursue those whom murder falls in with, i. e. who are ac- cidentally guilty of murder?

But the fact is that all through these lines there is an intentional use of mild terms, giving (as so often) the effect of the deadliest irony, and suggesting the grim exultant ferocity of the Furies. Thus, besides ξυμπέσωσι, befall, for a deliberate murder, we have μάταιοι (lit. vain, foolish,) for wicked: ὁμαρτεῖν (lit. to attend on), for the relentless pursuit of the Furies: οὐκ ἄγαν ἐλεύθερος meaning he is never quit of us.

Note the Epic usages: (1) τοῖσιν for relative, so, e. g. Ag. 526, 642, Cho. 604, Eum. 918, Theb. 519, etc.: (2) ξυμπέσωσιν, indef. subj. with no ἄν attached to the relative,-both common survivals in tragedy : and (3) ὄφρα ἄν for until.
λάχη. here, as 1. 334, office.
ἐκράνθη, assigned: so Suppl. 943 ψῆφος κέκρανται, fixed, settled.

ἀθανάτων δ᾽ ἀπέχειν χέρας, but from the immortals to keep away. The ἀθανάτων δέ is opposed to the θνατῶν of the previous stanza 1. 336. Their 'office' is to pursue the guilty man, but they have nothing to do with gods.

This line does not correspond to the antistrophic line,
Ζεὺς γὰρ αἱματοσταγὲς ἀξιόμισον ἔθνος τόδε λέσχας, but both make good sense, and there is no specially suspicious word in either. Under these circumstances it is quite easy to make them correspond in numerous different ways, by changing one, or the other, or both. But the best correction is to read ἀνέορτον for ἄμοιρον here, and in the antistrophe to read δ' αἱμοσταγές for γὰρ αἱματοσταγές. In pure white robes I have no festal part.

The Eumenides as nether and evil powers had 'no lot nor part' in the festivals of gods where white robes were worn: they were μελανεί- μονες, black-robed, 1. 376, μέλαιναι, 1. 52, φαιοχίτωνες, dusky in garb, Cho. 1048, as became daughters of Night.
Whenever the Wargod is tamed and slays a friend, an imaginative phrase, obscure from its very boldness: he means when Strife in the house sheds a kinsman's blood.

διόμεναι, Epic word, pursuing. Homer has it always transitive: here it seems best to take it intrans. with prep. 'pursuing after him.' [It might be tmesis for ἐπιδιόμεναι : but ὦ makes this less likely. Perhaps E. A. Ahrens' ὧδ' ἱέμεναι, which is certainly very ingenious, is the true reading.]
τόν, Epic demonst. use. [Others read ἐπιτόνως: but Schol. had our reading, for he remarks on the position of ὦ.]

11. 358, 9 are read in the MSS. :
κρατερὸν ὄνθ᾽ ὁμοίως
μαυροῦμεν ὑφ᾽ [or ἐφ᾽] αἵματος νέου, and in the antistrophe :
σφαλερὰ τανυδρόμοις
κῶλα δύσφορον ἄταν. The best emendation seems to be Weil's:
κρατερὸν ὄνθ᾽ ὅμως ἀμαυρ-
οῦμεν αἵματος νέου, and in the antistrophe:
σφαλερὰ τανυδρόμοις ὅμως
κῶλα, δύσφορον μάταν.

The meaning of the passage before us will then be:
After him pursuing,
Mighty though he be, we waste him away
For the new deed of blood.

The genitive will then be a genitive of the cause (like θράσους τοῦδ᾽ οὐκ ἀλύξεις Soph. Εl. 627, for this daring thou shalt not escape) or perhaps the more special gen. of the charge (like ἁλῶναι κλοπῆς, διώκειν φόνου, etc.).
For a fuller discussion see Appendix.

Again an obscure passage. MSS. read :
σπευδόμεναι δ᾽ ἀφελεῖν τινὰ τάσδε μερίμνας
θεῶν δ᾽ ἀτέλειαν ἐμαῖσι λιταῖς ἐπικραίνειν
μηδ᾽ ἐς ἄγκρισιν ἐλθεῖν·
Ζεὺς γὰρ αἱματοσταγὲς ἀξιόμισον ἔθνος τόδε λέσχας
ἃς ἀπηξιώσατο. And then should follow what has got displaced in the MSS.:
μάλα γὰρ οὖν ἁλομένα, κ.τ.λ.

Where the general drift seems to be: [I pursue the guilty] and am eager to relieve another (the gods) of this charge, and set the gods free, and prevent the crime from coming to trial-for Zeus has banished the guilty from his sight, etc.

This seems to make a fair sense, and it is best with most editors to suppose the nom. pendens σπευδόμεναι to be taken up again by μάλα γὰρ οὖν, so that the sentence is only grammatically completed when we reach καταφέρω.
[This anacoluthon is rather harsh: Wecklein and Kirchhoff take Döderlein's suggestion σπεύδομεν αΐδ', we here are eager. But the phrase is then abrupt and unnatural.]
The points that remain are:

(1) 362 ἐμαῖσι λιταῖς, which, if right, must be referred to the prayer of the Eumenides to Apollo not to interfere. But the passage is too general to refer specially to Orestes, though he is of course in their minds. So that perhaps ἐμαῖς μελέταις is better, and by my labour to set the gods free' (lit. 'to bring about the freedom or immunity of the gods,' i. e. freedom from the duty of punishing the criminal).

(2) 363 μηδ' εἰς ἄγκρισιν ἐλθεῖν: i. e. to take the guilty into my own hands and prevent the matter from being tried by the gods;- the very thing they feared was going to be done with Orestes. ἄγκρισις or ἀνάκρισις is the technical term for the preliminary investigation by a magistrate.

(3) Bloody hateful race, i.e. as Schol. explains, 'the race of murderers:' the whole passage from 1. 348 being a general description of the office of the Furies and their relation to the gods. [H. P. and others refer ἔθνοs to Furies: but they would hardly call themselves ἀξιώμισον.]

The whole passage may then be translated as follows:
And eager to lighten another of this charge,
And by our care to set free the gods,
And that [it] come not to trial:
For with this bloody hateful troop
Zeus deigns not to commune.

μάλα with ἁλομένα :
For mightily indeed leaping from on high
I bring down the weighty power of my foot-
Limbs which trip even the swiftest runner, - A toil intolerable.
The emendation adopted [ὅμως inserted and μάταν, see above 1. 359] is almost necessary to give the right sense, even though they fly swiftly.
ὑπ᾿ αἰθέρι, beneath the sky, i.e. when they are living on earth.

κατὰ γᾶν, on earth, is the MS. reading: but as Hermann said, the sense below the earth, κατὰ γᾶs, is required in antithesis to ὑπ᾿ αἰθέρι. The same mistake occurs again 11. 838, 871. 11. 375, 376. Bold and imaginative expressions :
Before our black-robed assault,
And the vengeful measures of our foot;
i.e. [their human glories come to naught] when we the Furies attack them and weave these magic dances which make them our captive (as we are doing to Orestes).
After this line in the MSS. comes μάλα γὰρ οὖν . . . μάταν (11. 367-371). It is possible that the words are repeated as a refrain both here and after 1. 380.

And though he falls, he knows not this in his witless ruin : λυμή is the destruction which attacks his mind, and blinds him to the threatening evil; τόδε is best taken (not of the fall as many edd., which would be simply πίπτων οὐκ οἶδεν, but) of the presence and power of the Furies.
κνέφας. is in apposition to μύσος, and is predicative: we should say, So dark a cloud of pollution hovereth over him.
ἐπί, Epic adverbial use (tmesis) of the preposition, going with the verb.

Again a highly imaginative and picturesque phrase which needs no alteration:
And the voice of many a groan
Proclaims against the house a mist of gloom.
The groans of the past victims are heard as it were making a horror of gloom about the house of wickedness.
μένει γάρ, for the law abides: so μίμνει Ag. 1563. But it is obscure and abrupt: and possibly corrupted.
The verb ἐσμέν is easily understood: Crafty are we, and unfailing to accomplish.

Speeding to do our office dishonoured, and unregarded,
Far apart from gods
Where no sunlight shines,-pathless and rugged alike
For the sightless and the seeing;
i.e. our pursuit which brings misery on living and dead alike: according to the oft-repeated idea that even in death the victim escapes not from the Furies: ὑπό τε γᾶν φυγὼν οὔ ποτ᾽ ἐλευθεροῦται 1. 175, θανὼν δ᾽ οὐκ ἄγαν ἐλεύθερος 1. 346. The sentence has no verb, and διόμεναι is rather a strange word (though the English to pursue a task or charge exactly illustrates it): hence Heath ingeniously suggested διέπο- μεν. But διόμεναι was read by Schol. and the MS. may stand.

ἀνηλίῳ λάμπᾳ, lit. in sunless light, an oxymoron, meaning in a light which is no light, where no sunlight shines. [Others translate λάμπᾳ, filth, mould; for there is a very late word λάμπη, 'scum; and Dind. adopts Wieseler's conj. λάπᾳ in the same sense. But the strain of meaning is very harsh, and the word in the last degree unlikely.]

δυσοδοπαίπαλα is suspicious, as the metaphor is rather harsh (though perhaps continued from διόμεναι): the metre does not correspond with the antistrophe (καίπερ ὑπὸ χθόνα); and the double compound with δυσ- is unusual, indeed unique.
There are many suggestions to cure the metrical fault, δυσποροπ., δυσποδοπ., δυσμολοπ., δυσβατοπ., etc. But it is best to leave it.
Compare ἀλαοῖσι καὶ δεδορκόσιν 1. 322.
δοθέντα τέλεον, adj. used proleptically, granted for sure ac- complishment.

Two syllables are wanting to make the metre correspond: and they are usually supplied among the iambics of 1. 394, with adop- tion of Hermann's κύρω for κῠρῶ; but possibly 1. 394 is all right, and the loss is in 1. 395.

p.stage: [Enter Athena from above in the air.]

div.p: [SCENE III. Athena comes, and seeing the chorus ques- tions them. They reply that Orestes is a murderer. Athena bids him tell the tale. He pleads that he is purified, and narrates the divine order, and the murder. Athena says she will not decide, but gather a court of judges to try the case.]

γῆν καταφθατουμένη. Some further alter γῆν into γῆς, and translate hastening from; but the land of Scamander would be a strange expression, and a much fuller and better sense is gained by translating καταφθατουμένη, occupying, hasting to claim the land. (So Hesych. who has καταφθατουμένη, κατακτωμένη.)

The Schol. tells us there was a reference here to a dispute between Athens and Mitylene for Sigeum in the Troad, settled in favour of M. by single combat. According to Herodotus (5.95) the dispute was an old one: the struggle began about 606, and was settled by mediation of
Periander, who gave Sigeum to Athens. But evidently the dispute went on: for Herodotus tells us in the same chapter that Peisistratos (presum- ably about 550 B.C.) conquered Sigeum. It is quite in Aeschylus' manner to refer to this event in a bold and imaginative way, by making the land given to Athena as choice offering of the spoil by the chiefs of Achaioi. There was a temple of Athena on the promontory.
αὐτόπρεμνον, bold metaphor, root and branch, i. e. utterly, land and all therein.

ἐξαίρετον. : it was a custom, from Homer's time, to take out of the spoil a special gift for kings (or, as here, gods). So Homer fre- quently γέρας ἔξελον υἱὲς Ἀχαιῶν. So Thucydides tells us at the destruc- tion of Mitylene (3. 30) the Athenians made 3000 holdings of the land, and 300 of these τοῖς θεοῖς ἱεροὺς ἐξεῖλον.

Flapping the fold of my aegis in wingless flight, a splendid and picturesque line: the goddess needing no wing to fly, the aegis serves her as a wing, and is accompanied with the ῥοῖβδος or whirring noise of wings.

The αἰγίς was the wonderful shield of Zeus gleaming and fringed, that Hephaistos made (and therefore metal), Iliad 15. 307: it was tasselled, crowned about with Terror, and Strife, and Might, and fearful Fray is therein, and the dread monster's Gorgon head, Iliad 5. 738. Athena wears it also, as well as Zeus, in Homer. The word probably meant storm or rushing originally (αἰγ- ἀϊσσω) : but later it was conceived as a goatskin (αἴγ), and so here has a κόλπος or fold.

Yoking to this car my lusty steeds: if we understand this (with Schol.) literally, as though she came in the air on a car drawn by steeds, the phrase ἄτρυτον πόδα, and the previous line, seem to lose their point. Wakef. (followed by H. Hart. Schöm. and others) read κώλοις, legs, a most clumsy emendation, and quite inappropriate to ἐπιζεύξασ᾽ ὄχον. You can't talk of yoking a car on your legs. It is better to take it metaphorically: the ὄχος is the aegis, the πῶλοι are the winds. So exactly Aristophanes calls Athena αἰγίδος ἠνιόχος Clouds 602.

ὑμᾶς θ᾽, the construction is irregular but natural: she means, and you [I call] like to no race begotten, etc. (or perhaps even a stronger verb of abuse is meant to finish the sentence): but she checks herself 1. 413.

The MSS. reading ἄμορφον (retained by Dind. Weck. and read by Schol.) is translated, For neighbours to revile a hideous monster is far from justice, which is rather crude and inappropriate; and ὄντα, idiomatic with the subject, is hardly grammar when it constitutes the object. Robor- telli's ἄμομφον makes excellent sense: but for one who is not aggrieved (lit. who has no wrong to complain of) to revile others is unjust.
(This is confirmed by 1. 678, where Ven. reads again ἄμορφος for ἄμομφος.)
ἀποστατεῖ θέμις, Right holds aloof, stately phrase for ,it is wrong,.

It is doubtful whether to read αἰανῆ (from αἰανής) or αἰανῆς (from αἰανός). M. G. and Schol. read here αἰανῆ (agreeing with τέκνα) and αἰανής is the ordinary form used elsewhere by Aeschylus, αἰανῆ χρόνον 1. 572, αἰανὴς νόσος 11. 479, 941. On the other hand, Hesychius (Alexandrine grammarian and lexicographer, 4th century, A.D.) quotes a form αἰανός, usually read in Soph. El. 506 ἔμολες αἰανή. In Soph. Aias 672 there is the same doubt as here, whether to read νυκτὸς αἰανῆς κύκλος, or αἰανής. But both there and here it is rather more natural to have adj. agreeing with νυκτός: and here particularly: accord- ingly I take αἰανῆς, the reading of Fl. Fa. Ven.

As to the meaning: the word certainly sometimes means eternal (αἰανῆ χρόνον 1. 572, αἰανῶς μένοι 1. 672): but it also is used in the sense of grievous, terrible, (αἰανὴς κόρος, αἰανὲς κέντρον Pind., αἰανὲς δεῖπνον Archil.). Either sense will suit here: perhaps eternal is the most impressive,
ἐν οἴκοις γῆς ὕπαι, not for τοῖς γῆς ὕπαι, but 'in our home, beneath the earth, both phrases going with verb κεκλήμεθα.
ἐπωνύμους, not in its usual sense called after; but simply 'the names men call you by.'
γε μὲν δή, adversative as usual. My office, however, thou shalt learn. So Ag. 661, 887, 1213.
I might learn, if one would show a plain tale; a touch of ironic scorn for the dark hints of the Chorus.

μηδαμοῦ:. the μή generalises as usual: Some place where joy is all unknown: the Chorus mean in Hades: but the indefinite or generic way of putting it is quite idiomatic and more imaginative and impressive. μηδαμοῦ νομίζεται, lit. is held of no account.
ἐπιρροιζεῖν, to clamour after, of noisy and terrifying pursuit ; To such a flight do ye hound him on?
ἠξιώσατο, took on him, rarely med. Cp. Ag. 370 θεοὺς ἀξιοῦσθαι.
i. e. Did he not do it, fearing the wrath of some other power? Apollo is meant; only instead of naming him, she uses the vaguer word ἀνάγκη.
There is no need to alter the line: the Schol. quotes and explains it thus.
ὡς often used for ὥστε in poetry: Epic usage.

There are two suitors here, and we have heard but half the pleas, i.e. we must wait till we have heard both sides. The reading of
Μ. ἥμισυς λόγου is regular Attic use (as well as λόγος): τῇ ἡμισέᾳ τῆς γῆς Thuc., ὁ ἥμισυς τοῦ ἀριθμοῦ Plat.

(The correction θέλοι for θέλει is almost necessary, as otherwise it would seem as if the proposal had been made to Orestes.) The reference in this line, he would take no oath, nor challenge us to swear, is to the custom of the ἀνάκρισις or preliminary investigation of causes at Athens, before a magistrate: at this all the evidence was produced; and the first thing was for the injured party to swear (προωμοσία) he had suffered, the defendant to swear (ἀνθωμοσία) he was innocent.

These oaths, say the Chorus, are impossible here: Orestes will not deny his guilt: he will neither ask us to swear (δοῦναι) nor swear when we ask him (δέξασθαι). The whole of this passage is intended to correspond in a general way to the ἀνάκρισις: after hearing the preliminary state- ment of either party, Athena refers the whole case to the formal judgment of the Areiopagos.
The name of Just, not Justice, is thy desire, δίκαια being easily supplied with πρᾶξαι. She means: just forms, rather than justice.
σοφῶν, subtlety.

I say that injustice must not prevail by oaths, i.e. the issue must not be settled by oaths, but by the real justice of the case. Prac- tically, Athena admits that Orestes cannot swear his innocence, but pleads that in this exceptional case it must not go against him for that: the true issue (εὐθυδικία) must be tried; see next note.
εὐθεῖαν δίκην, poet. for εὐθυδικία, the regular legal term for the 'real issue' opposed to some side question.
ἐπὶ . . . τρέποιτ', entrust, more frequently in the compound ἐπιτρέπω. The separate form (tmesis) is found in poetry, e. g. Ant. 1107 μηδ᾽ ἐπ᾿ ἄλλοισιν τρέπε.
τέλος, the final settlement, the decision.' Somewhat similar is Ag. 934 ἐξεῖπον τέλος.

κἀπ᾿ ἀξίων (Arnald's correction, adopted by Paley, must be right), a worthy child of worthy sire, i.e. a great goddess, and daughter of Zeus. So Schol. ἀξίων οὖσαν γονέων. [Other corrections numerous, but all less simple and natural.]

Ixion killed Deioneus, his mother's father, by treachery at a banquet by preparing a pit into which he fell. Pindar says (Pyth. 2. 31) that he was the first of men to shed kindred blood. When all shunned him for the guilt, Zeus took pity on him and purified him. Of course a connection was felt between the name Ιξίων and ἱκ-, the root of the words of supplication: possibly even the origin of the story is to be sought there.
τούτοις πᾶσιν, neut. to all this, i. e. the accusation of the Eumenides.
MSS. read ἔχει μύσος, and ἐφεζομένη, which has neither sense nor metre. ἐφημένου and ἐφημένη have been suggested; but no tolerable construction has been made of the line.
I follow Weil. Kirch. Weckl. in adopting Wieseler's far better emendation ἔχων... ἐφεζόμην: the corruption of ἐφεζόμην entailed that of the other.
Nor with pollution on my hand did I fall suppliant before thy image.
Till by the hand of the purifier of murder the blood of the slain suckling besprinkle him.

The form of purification was with water and the blood of a pig, which was commonly used at Athens in such καθάρσεις: e.g. in purifying the space where the public meetings were held: [ἐντὸς τοῦ καθάρματος Ar. Ach. 44.]
οἴκοισι. is governed by πρός: the other datives are instrumental.
πόρος, stream, is frequent in Aeschylus.
ἐκποδῶν λέγω, I speak away the misgiving: rather bold use of the words, but unmistakeable.
The order is Τροίαν Ἰλίου πόλιν ἄπολιν ἔθηκας. The Schol. remarks on the skill of Orestes in conciliating Athena by reminding her of the former bond between her and Agamemnon.
ποικίλοις, crafty.

That bare witness to the murder in the bath: for Klytaimne- stra had cast the robe about Agamemnon like a net (ἄγρευμα) in the bath and stabbed him and Orestes (Choeph. 980) had held up the bloody robe before the Chorus as a proof and reminder of her deed.
The terrible penalties threatened if the avenger neglected his duty are given in a fine passage, Choeph. 271-296. ἀντίκεντρα, like a spur, see 11. 38, 136.

πράξας πανταχή, idiomatic use for howsoe'er I fare. So Antig. 634 πανταχῆ δρῶντες φίλοι, howsoe'er we act, we are dear. ἐν σοί commonly in thy power' with the verb to be : ἐν τῷ δαίμονι Ο. Τ. 1443, ἐν σοὶ ἐσμέν ib. 314, ἐν θεῷ τὸ τέλος ἦν Dem. 292. Here it has rather a different shade of meaning, at thy hands, under thy rule.

The matter is too hard, if any mortal thinks to judge it; this, the translation of the MSS. reading, εἴ τις, makes very good sense: μεῖζον is used for μεῖζον ἢ ὥστε δικάζειν, which is easily supplied. The Schol. also takes it so, apparently. It must be referred, not to a mortal, -not even to a god: but to a divinely appointed solemn court of judges. [Others read ἤ τις, harder (than any mortal thinks) to judge: which is rather flat sense. The Schol. plainly read eἴ, not ἤ. The confusion of ei and ἤ is very common in the MSS. of Aeschylus.]
ὀξυμηνίτους is used in a slightly predicative sense, to decide with swift vengeance the issues of murder: it is the decision which brings the vengeance.

ἄλλως τε καὶ σύ, especially since thou, the causal conjunction being omitted by a looseness due to Aeschylus' bold brevity. Literally it is Both on other grounds (this is so) and (chiefly as) thou hast come. κατηρτυκώς, a hard word. καταρτίω is to fit, train, finish, and this perf. is used intransitively, in a kind of technical sense, of animals, mature, complete (so Schol. and Hesych. say), hence it is here meta- phorical, of the suppliant; with all due rites performed. [In a similar metaphor Euripides (Frag. 39) uses the phrase κατηρτυκὼς πόνων, which has been misunderstood from not observing the context. Had I been new to trouble I should have resisted, like a colt newly bridled: but now I am spent (ἀμβλύς) and well trained in toils,' i.e. broken in, the phrase continuing the metaphor of the colt.]
ἀβλαβής, harmless, as 1. 285.

MSS. read ὅμως δ': but the adversative nevertheless seems out of place, and there is no sense in saying You are now pure, nevertheless I receive you: moreover the strongly emphatic σὺ μέν requires a personal antithesis. Accordingly I follow Hartung in reading ἐγὼ δέ.
αἱροῦμαι πόλει, I take thee, welcome thee in my city.

μοῖραν οὐκ εὐπέμπελον, lit. an office hard to banish, i. e. such is their office, they are hard to banish: the rights which the appointment of the gods has given them makes it hard for me to deal harshly with them.
χώρᾳ, put first to emphasise what is affected, is in sense dependent on ἄφερτος αἰανὴς νόσος.

The construction μὴ τυχοῦσαι ... ἰὸς πεσὼν νόσος is the not uncommon anacoluthon called nominativus pendens: compare Ag. 1008 ὄκνος βαλὼν οὐκ ἔδυ δόμος, Theb. 681 θάνατος ὧδ᾽ αὐτοκτόνος οὐκ ἔστι γῆρας τοῦδε, Cho. 520 πάντα γάρ τις ἐκχέας ... μάτην ὁ μόχθος. So Cho. 791, Soph. O. C. 1150.
φρονημάτων, wrath.

ἀμφότερα . . . ἐμοί to let them stay, to drive them forth, both are a peril and a perplexity to me. The change of subject with the inf. (that they should stay, that I should drive) is much less harsh in Greek: the inf. expresses the simple verbal idea, and the subject need not be consciously supplied.

δεῦρ᾽ ἐπέσκηψεν, has fallen to me, i. e. to arrange. 11. 483, 4. The general sense of these lines is plain: but the MS. reading requires to be altered, and the original text must remain C
uncertain: I have taken Casaubon's ὁρκίους αἱρουμένη as the least alteration on the whole: I shall choose judges of murder bound by oaths, and appoint them as an ordinance for ever. τόν then agrees with θεσμόν, an ordinance that which [shall be] for all time. But Wecklein's φανῶ δικ. ὁρκίων αἰδουμένους θεσμόν, is ingenious.]

ἀρωγὰ ὁρκώματα, apposition to μαρτύρια: Summon evi- dence and proof, sworn testimony in aid of justice. The Scholiast says ὅρκους αὐτοὺς αἰτήσατε, misunderstanding apparently ὁρκώματα to refer to the judges' oath, whereas it is best to refer it to the oath of witnesses. There is no need to insert θ' before ὁρκώματα, as H. Weil.
τὰ βέλτατα, abstract collective for τοὺς βελτίστους. So τάδε μὲν Περσῶν Pers. 1, τὰ πρῶτα τῆς μοχθηρίας Ar. Ran. 421.
διαιρεῖν. is epexegetic or consec. inf., that they should decide, the subject being carried on in sense from τὰ βέλτατα, becoming (naturally) masc. in the participle, next line.

The MSS. ὅρκον περῶντας μηδὲν ἔκδικον φρεσίν is obviously corrupt: and I take the easiest correction which gives any natural sense, πορόντας (Herm.) and φράσειν (Markland)- Swearing an oath to utter naught unjust. πορόντας will then be poetic equivalent for the ordinary διδόντας (or rather δόντας) by which the Schol. interprets it.
Both errors are of the kind due to the text being dictated and misheard.
[The line is misplaced by V. Fl. after 1. 484, and omitted by Fa., and hence some have thought it spurious. But its very corruption is in favour of its genuineness.]

[SECOND STASIMON. If Orestes goes unscathed, many a crime shall follow: let not the victims then call on our help. Fear should be somewhere enthroned in the State: and all excess, of license or tyranny, is evil. Those who reverence right shall live: the wicked shall perish in the storm; he shall call and none shall hear: he shall be lost for ever.]

Now shall come changes to new laws; rather an unusual use of the gen., though possible: we have (Thucyd. 6. 18) μεταβολὴ ἀπραγμοσύνης, change to timid policy, in a very similar use. [The best alteration is νόμων θεσμίων τ' (L. Schmidt): but it is not so forcible as the text, and not necessary.]

δίκα τε καὶ βλάβα, the cause and the wrong: the strong contradiction in terms (oxymoron), which comes out in the Greek more than in the English, is intentional and effective: Orestes' δίκα was ἄδικος and βλαβερά in the eyes of the Eumenides.

Hereafter this deed shall set all men's hand to license, is the meaning: literally it is, shall join all mortals to readiness (of sin). The commentators aptly quote Plat. Rep. 391 Ε πολλὴν εὐχέρειαν πονηρίας.
παιδότρωτα πάθεα, woful wounds dealt by a child, woes from the murderous hands of children.

And, for not even from the Furies that watch mankind Shall wrath for these deeds Come upon any man-I will let loose all murder upon them; reading οὐδέ for οὔτε, with most edd., and τιν' for τις with Weil, μαινάδων is subjective gen., τῶνδε ἐργμάτων objective, both after κότος. The γάρ gives the reason for ἐφήσω; which is common enough when ἀλλά precedes, but unusual (as here) with no such connection.

And one man shall ask of another
As he tells of his neighbours' woes,
That trouble may cease and be diminished :
And the hapless man gives comfort in vain,
Speaking of cures that profit not.
There is a grandeur and impressiveness of gloomy prophecy which almost remind one of the Hebrew prophets or poets of the Old Testament.
In this fine stanza the Erinyes speak as the Powers of Justice which the gods have overthrown: The afflicted shall call upon us, but we will not hear is what, in effect, they say.
Somewhere should fear abide enthroned, watching the heart of man; tis well to be chastened with suffering.
The doctrine that suffering brings wisdom is a favourite Aeschylean maxim, τὸν πάθει μάθος θέντα κυρίως ἔχειν Ag. 177.

The MSS. read :
τίς δὲ μηδὲν ἐν φάει
καρδίαν ἀνατρέφων
ἢ πόλις, κ.τ.λ.
The general sense is plain : 'who, if he have nought to fear will any longer be just?' But the text as it stands is corrupt, and as it is easy to rewrite the two lines to give the right sense, there are a vast number of suggestions, none convincing ;—

(1) Some (Pal. Well. others) retain the first line and read καρδίας: who, if he cherish no [fear] in the gaiety of his heart..., but it is hardly credible that the principal idea, fear should be understood from the last stanza: and therefore-

(2) The best emendation (without too much alteration) is the old one of Auratus (Herm. Weckl. Schütz. D.)-
τίς δὲ μηδὲν ἐν δέει
καρδίαν ἀνατρέφων, κ.τ.λ.
who, if he do not train his heart in fear, etc.... There is a further question whether we should keep 1. 522 κᾶρδῖ- | ᾶν ӑ- | νᾱτρε- | φῶν or make the correspondence with 1.512 exact, by inserting ἄν; κᾱρδῐ- | ᾱν ᾰν | ἄνᾰτρě- | φῶν. It is perhaps better to insert the av : though the thrice repeated syllable -av- is a little rough.
ἢ ... τε is irregular : whether city or man we must say in English.
ἀνάρχετον. (read for metre's sake), like ἀπεύχετον Cho. 625.

παντὶ μέσῳ, ever to the mean god gives success: a common Greek maxim: so Ag. 378 ἔστω δ᾽ ἀπήμαντον ὥστ᾽ ἀπαρκεῖν, ib. 466 τὸ δ᾽ ὑπερκόπως εὖ κλύειν βαρὺ κρίνω δ᾽ ἄφθονον ὄλβον, etc., the idea being that excess was dangerous: so Eur. Fr. 80 τὰ μείζω τῶν μέσων τίκτει νόσους.
ἐφορεύει, directs.

ξύμμετρον. seems best taken as timely, fitting: a rather fanciful way of saying wise. [Others take it in accord with this, i.e. with the doctrine of moderation: which is a possible meaning and may be defended: only the main point of all this chorus is the need of repressing crime and licence, and the doctrine of moderation is rather a digression.]
This notion, that crime leads to new crime, is familiar from the Agamemnon: τὸ δυσσεβές γὰρ ἔργον μετὰ μὲν πλείονα τίκτει 1. 759, ὕβρις παλαιὰ νεάζουσαν ὕβριν τίκτει 1. 763.

I take H.'s correction πάμφιλος for πᾶσι φίλος and Hartung's δόμων for δωμάτων 1. 547 : the alternative (to read πᾶσιν, and change the order of δωμάτων ἐπιστροφάς) really alters the text as much, and produces a less likely metre.
ἐς τὸ πᾶν, for whate'er befall; i. e. as the first and greatest rule of life.
κύριον μένει τέλος, the appointed end abideth: only an impressive way of saying that good and evil alike shall meet their deserts.
ξενοτίμους δόμων ἐπιστροφάς, κ.τ.λ., literally, [let him re- vere] guest-honouring visits of the house: a characteristically elabo- rated expression for hospitable welcome.

οὐκ ἄνολβος ἔσται, understatement such as is natural and common in Greek, shall not fail to prosper. 11. 553, 4. If the reading is right, the acc. τὰ πολλὰ παντόφυρτ᾽ is
