governed by the verbal idea in παραιβάταν: The man who dares to resist and commits all manner of transgressions, swerving from Right: such accusatives after verbals are rather in the manner of Aeschylus : θυμοβόρου φρένα Ag. 103, πολλὰ συνίστορα ib. 1090, ἄπορα πόριμος Prom. 904, χοὰς προπομπός Cho. 23, ἀπότροπον ἄγος ib. 155. (So Schol.) Of the corrections proposed Pauw's is the best ... παντόφυρτ᾽ ἄγοντ᾽ ἄνευ (reading παρβάταν for καὶ παραιβάταν), bringing much confusion : but though the grammar is smoother, the sense is weaker.

βιαίως, perforce, i. e. the storm shall compel him. καθήσειν, shall lower sail, i. e. shall be made humble and sub- missive; so ὑφέσθαι is used Ar. Ran. 1220 ὑφέσθαι μοι δοκεῖ, Soph. Εl. 335 πλεῖν ὑφειμένῃ δοκεῖ. [It is far better to make καθήσειν absolute, and make λαῖφος governed by λάβῃ, than with H. to write καθήσειν λαῖφος, ὅταν λάβῃ, κ.τ.λ. The metaphor is then more gradually and naturally introduced: the rhythm is more effective: and also the Schol. clearly takes καθήσειν by itself, for he explains it ταπεινωθήσεται. Such curtailments are common in technical expressions, e. g. in English, luff, put about, lower away.]
πόνος, trouble, a word suggestive from its mildness: he means the hurricane.

δυσπαλεῖ, taken by some as a verb (Pal. Verrall): but the adj. δυσπαλής is used by Pindar, while the verb is unknown. The sense is equally good, if we take it adj., and the run of the sentence more easy.
θερμῷ, headstrong, rash, as often in Greek.
τὸν οὔποτ᾽ αὐχοῦντ᾽, who boasted he ne'er [should suffer], boasted it ne'er should be, the negative used just as in οὔ φημι, οὐκ ἂν ᾤετο, οὐκ ἀξιῶ, etc. So οὔποτ᾽ ἐλπίσαντες, Agam. 1044.
Wrecking his happiness on the reef of justice: the fine metaphor is kept up to the end.

[SCENE IV, Part 1. Athena returns with the Areiopagites, Apollo, and Orestes. The deed is proved, Apollo expounds the justice of the case, and it is argued out. Athena presides, and calls for a vote. The votes are equal, Orestes is acquitted. He gives thanks and retires. Apollo also goes out.]

The difficulty is to fill up the gap in the MS. line here, ἥ τ᾽ οὖν διάτορος Τυρσηνική. Scholefield conjectured oὖr to be a cor- ruption (from contraction) of οὐρανοῦ, and Paley suggested the reading εἶθ᾽ ἡ διάτορος οὐρανοῦ. [Better Weckl. εἰς οὐρανὸν δὲ δ. τ.] But as there is a gap in 3 MSS. after διάτορος, it is better to take a suggestion of Emper's διάτορος αἰθέρος, or Ahrens' διάτορος ἀέρος, supposing the gen. lost owing to its similarity to the termination of διάτορος.
The Tyrrhenian' trumpet, because the Tyrrhenians or Etruscans were from very early times celebrated as workers in bronze: in poetry the adj. seems specially given to the trumpet: thus Eur. Phoen. 1377 Τυρσηνικῆς σάλπιγγος ἠχή, Soph. Αi. 17 κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς, Verg. Aen. 8. 506 Tyrrhenusque tubae. . clangor.' The anachronism (noticed by the Scholiast) is of a kind common enough.
ἀρήγει, it helps, i. e. 'tis good.

The MSS. read τόνδ' or τῶνδ': the pronoun must be plural, for it must mean the Areopagitae (as Schol. explains it): to take it singular for Orestes makes no real sense with the rest of the line. The gen. is the difficulty, and perhaps points to a lost line as H. Weil. think: but on the whole it is best to read τούσδ' and to suppose τῶνδ' a blunder possibly due to καταγνωσθῇ, which in another sense ('to decide against') often takes gen.
ὧν ἔχεις αὐτὸς κράτει, 'rule thou thine own domain, like the proverbial τὴν σαυτοῦ πάτει, i. e. mind your own business.
MSS. end the line δόμων, which with δόμων next line is intolerable. I take νόμῳ, correction of Erf. and Burgess, and approved by H.
σύνδικος. is an advocate. Apollo says he will be Orestes' advocate, as he is responsible for the murder.
κυροῦν, usually to confirm, here in the rather unusual sense of to settle, as below again 1. 639.

This is already one of the three wrestling-falls, alluding to the custom of deciding the wrestling combat by three falls: when a man was defeated thrice, he was beaten. So διὰ τριῶν ἀπόλλυμαι Eur. Or. 434, and the word τριακτήρ Ag. 171 for a conqueror, lit. one who throws thrice.
γε μέντοι, as usual, adversative, however.'
No need to alter λέγω (Μ. P. A.) into λέξω. The vivid present is natural enough.
πρὸς τοῦ, ‘by whom,' common variation in poetry for ὑπό. So we find ἐκ, ἀπό, παρά, with gen. of agent. See 100.
The ye, as usual, assenting and adding a further point: 'ay, and till now I do not complain of my lot:' i. e. not literally that he had not suffered, but that Apollo had helped him.

πέπεισθι, exceptional reduplicated aorist imperative with intransitive meaning: trust now in the dead. The form somewhat resembles the Epic κέκλυθι, τέτλαθι, and κέκραχθι (Ach. 335); but has the heavier stem-form.
The Chorus speak of course with bitter irony.

Schol. takes προσβολάς as 'the meeting' of two pollutions, but there is no need to take it as different from its ordinary meaning, a putting or rubbing or striking of one thing against another: the pollutions strike her, not each other. So it is used, Ag. 391, of rubbing metal against a touchstone: Cho. 283 of attacks of Furies-
Ay, for a double stain fell on her.
The dè-clause contains the real predicate as often; the μὲν-clause points the antithesis: Therefore while thou livest [unpurged] she is free by her death.

An extreme instance of the sharp distinction felt (1. 212) by the Greeks between murdering a blood-relation and an outsider. The wife not being a blood-relation was, according to the doctrine of the Eumenides here put forward, not liable to their pursuit for slaying her husband. The doctrine however fluctuates: in Cho. 923-4 Klyt. tries to deter Orestes by the threat that her Furies (ἐγκότους κύνας) will pursue him if he slays her, but he replies τὰς τοῦ πατρὸς δὲ πῶς φύγω παρεὶς τάδε; and in Sophokles, Elektra 112, the daughter prays the dread divine Erinyes to avenge her father's murder; and the Chorus (490) prophesy that with the tramp of many feet, and the might of many hands, the brazenfooted Erinyes shall come.
The bearing of this question is explained below 1. 660, when Apollo lays down the principle that the real parent is the father.
ὥσπερ ἐστίν, i. e. as done it is.
θεσμόν, ordinance, means here (as in 1. 484) the court of Areiopagos; and so the Scholiast explains it. It is therefore in ap- position to ὑμᾶς.
μή. generic, with the indef. opt. κελεύσαι: nothing which Zeus bade not, nothing save what Zeus bade.

πιφαύσκω, ‘I bid :' nearly all the words of speaking can be so used, λέγω, εἶπον, etc. The displacement of the dé is common. ὔμμε, Aeolic form of ὑμᾶς found several times in Homer. So ἄμμι (ἡμῖν) Theb. 156, ὔμμε Antig. 846, both however in lyric passages. [There is no need of alterations, as Hartung thinks.]
i.e. follow Zeus' will [even if you think it unjust]: for no oath [such as you swore, 1. 489, to do justice] is stronger than Zeus.
Here and 1. 657 Apollo acts in the character of the ἐξηγητής or expounder of the law, usually consulted about ancient or sacred customs. See Introd. p. 16.
Schol. tells us that Epicharmos (comic poet 540-450, who knew Aeschylus and lived with him some time at the court of Hiero) criticised him for his fondness for this word τιμαλφεῖν.
ὥστε, Epic, common in Trag. for ὡς.

A passage of well-known difficulty. The MSS. reading (with slight corrections, see critical notes) is substantially the fol- lowing:
ἀπὸ στρατείας γάρ νιν ἠμποληκότα
τὰ πλεῖστ᾽ ἄμεινον εὔφροσιν δεδεγμένη
δροίτῃ περῶντι λουτρὰ κἀπὶ τέρματι
φᾶρος παρεσκήνωσεν, ἐν δ᾽ ἀτέρμονι
κόπτει πεδήσασ᾽ ἄνδρα δαιδάλῳ πέπλῳ·
which it is possible to translate, as follows:
For him from the wars (returning) having dealt
In most things prosperously, she welcomed with kindly words,
And over the bath, as he stepped from the water, and on the edge,
She threw a cloak for covering, and entangling her lord
In a broidered robe inextricable, she smote him...
This makes good sense, and is in substance no doubt what the poet meant. But several things are at least suspicious: ἠμποληκότα τὰ πλεῖστ᾽ ἄμειvov is a harsh phrase, even if we justify the rather flat τὰ πλεῖστα and the comparative ἄμειvov by supposing an intentional understatement: εὔφροσιν without substantive is very harsh, and is hardly supported by the Homeric κερτομίοισιν and μειλιχίοισιν which are special idioms: δροίτῃ governed by παρεσκήνωσε, and λουτρά separate from it, is clumsy: κἀπὶ τέρματι is not smooth, and is sus- piciously like ἀτέρμονι in the line below: finally most of the MSS. and Schol. read περεσκήνωσεν, for περιεσ-, unexampled in Attic. Corruption is almost certain: but as sense can be made, and no suggestions are really satisfactory¹, it is best to leave it.
ταύτην, Klytaimnestra.
προτιμᾷ, most regards: i. e. counts it of more importance, as a more heinous sin, to slay him.
ὑμᾶς, the judges, as the Scholiast says.
ἂν λύσειεν, quite general, fetters may be loosed: not 'Zeus' only, but anyone, may loose them.

For this sentiment, the keynote of the three plays, see 1. 261. 1 Hartung, Wakefield, Burgess rewrite the passage: Paley reads ἅμ' αἴνοις for ἄμεινον, harsh in itself, and leaving ἠμποληκότα untranslateable; Bothe and Butler ἢ φράσαι for εὔφροσιν, ingenious, but rather too strong: H. Schütz, Linwood, Rauchenstein suppose a lacuna. Wellauer says 'procul dubio corrupta.' Weckl. also leaves a lacuna.
It strikes a modern reader as a grotesque defence of Zeus for his unfilial act, to say Fetters can be undone.
ἐπῳδάς. So Ag. 1019, 'The black blood once fallen on the earth who can call back with charms?'
All else he turns about, setting them high or low as he will.
Beware how thou pleadest for him, that he be acquitted; the τὸ φεύγειν being a kind of consecutive infinitive, giving the desired result of the pleading.
τὸ μητρὸς αἱμ' ὅμαιμον, his mothers kindred blood,' the attribute μητρὸς ὅμαιμον being divided, as often.

The Phratriai or ‘clans' were originally sub-divisions of the four old Ionic Tribes into which Athenians were grouped. There were twelve phratries, and they were based on a real or supposed kinship. The annual clan festival was the Apatouria (festival of those who had the same father, ἀ- πατήρ). And the 'purification with water' (χέρνιψ) was the common preliminary to these, as to all rites in temples or house- hold gatherings: the bloodguilty being naturally excluded from all.

The Med. reads κεκλημένου, while Ven. Flor. Farn. read κεκλημένη. Both make sense: (1) κεκλημένου: 'the mother of the so-called child is not the parent.' (2) κεκλημένη: ‘the so-called mother is not the parent of the child.' But it is obvious that τέκνου and τοκεύς are opposed, the sense re- quired being ' it is called her τέκνον, but she is not the τοκ-εύς really :' and therefore it is best to take (1), the Medicean reading κεκλημένου.
κῦμα, from kv-, which has the ideas of bulging, swelling, containing, hence κῦμα is the young in the womb, more commonly κύημα. So Cho. 121.
ὁ θρώσκων, he who begets, the male. The strange doctrine is that the father who begets is the real parent (τίκτει), the mother a stranger, ξένη, who only cherishes the child for another.
οἷσι μὴ βλάψῃ θεός, ‘save what the god blights,' i.e. 'except the god blight it, the plural relative after ἔpvos being a natural laxity of grammar.
[The indef. subj. without av is an Epic use, common in Tragedy. Note also ἔσωσεν gnomic aor.]

οὐδ.' has troubled editors: H. Butl. (Dind. Weil, etc.) suppose a line fallen out: Schütz reads οὐκ. I do not see that alteration is necessary if a slight pause is made at πάρεστι :
Close at hand
There is a witness, daughter of Olympian Zeus, -
And not nursed in the darkness of the womb,
But such a sprout,' etc.
[No sense can be got by taking οὐδέ, not even, as Pal. following Wel- lauer.] The and couples the explanatory clause, as te in Ag. 1526.
τἄλλα. θ' answers to καὶ τόνδ' ἔπεμψα. τἄλλα is expanded into τὸ σὸν πόλισμα καὶ στρατόν.

That their posterity should cherish this faithful bond:' the emphasis of this wish for permanence is really a political allusion. Not long before the date of the play (which is generally put at 458 B.C.) the Argives had become allied with Athens. The picture of Orestes the Argive, fleeing for refuge to Athens, had therefore a significance from a political point of view, which is of course only lightly touched, but is not lost sight of. See below 1. 765, and Introduction.

ἀπὸ γνώμης, from his judgment (gen. of the source), i.e. according to his judgment. Somewhat similar are τλήμων οὖσ᾽ ἀπ᾿ εὐτόλμου φρενός Ag. 1302, ἀπὸ γλώσσης, ‘by word of mouth,' ἀπ᾿ ὄψεως, at sight.

The sense is improved by marking this line as interrogative. Athena first asks the Furies whether they are willing to have the voting, and then the other side, Apollo and Orestes. Both express satisfaction, and then she gives her final address and orders them to vote. κελεύω will then be subj. delib. Shall I now order?' etc. It is a formal re- quest to both sides to know if there is anything more to be said: no doubt a copy of the usual proceeding on the part of the presiding judge at an Areopagite trial.
τιθεῖσ', ordering. Athena addresses Apollo and Orestes, but Apollo replies to the judges.

Athena having formally to address the court, takes this opportunity of solemnly instituting the Areiopagos for ever. [Kirch. Weckl. etc. transfer this speech to 573: but the close of the speech shows that it comes just before the voting.]
The names Aigeus, Theseus, Amazons, are brought in to emphasize the antiquity and glory of this Athenian institution.

᾿Αμαζόνων ἕδραν. One of the exploits of Theseus was an attack on the warrior women, called Amazons, when he carried off their queen Antiope. In revenge the Amazons invaded Attica, and were not defeated till they had reached the centre of Athens itself. The grammar is broken, and the provisional accusative πάγον δ᾽ ῎Αρειον τόνδ' in the course of the long sentence is forgotten; there is nothing to govern it. So O. T. 449. But it may be that ῎Αρειον is a gloss, which has ousted the verb: so Weil reads ἑδοῦνται, Weckl. ἑδεῖται.
κατὰ φθόνον, in hate, spite, slightly strained use.
πόλιν νεόπτολιν τήνδ' ἀντεπύργωσαν, 'raised this new city rampart against' the old: i. e. fortified the Areiopagos against the Akropolis.
τῷ, it, Epic use of article as pronoun, common in Aeschylus.
φόβος τε ξυγγενής, ‘and fear his kinsman.' Aeschylus is fond of such sudden personifications. So Ag. 494 he still more quaintly calls dust the neighbour brother of clay, κάσις πηλοῦ ξύνουρος.
σχήσει, ‘shall restrain them.'
I take the simplest alteration, ἐπικαινούντων for ᾿πικαινόντων of MSS., and leave the stop at νόμους.

[Others (H. D. Hart.) run on the sense to ἐπιρροαῖσι, to avoid leaving 1. 694 unconnected; but the rhythm is easier if we end at 1. 693 after the long passage: κακ. ἐπ. goes better with what follows than with ἐπικαινούντων: and as to the want of connexion, we have a similar instance in Ag. 322 ὄξος τ᾽ ἄλειφά τ᾽ ἐγχέας ταὐτῷ κύτει . . ., Eur. Or. 232 μεταβολὴ πάντων γλυκύ In all three cases, a proverb is quoted in support of what goes before.]
Same sentiment 1. 526.

περιστέλλουσι, lit. wrapping round, i.e. protecting, maintaining. Aeschylus protests against the despot (who was no longer formidable) and anarchy: i. e. he recommends oligarchy under the usual pretext of moderation.
The same sentiment as the Furies had expressed before, 1. 516, that Fear is necessary to the moral order of men and states, is here adopted by Athena.
Such majesty if ye justly revere ye shall find, etc.: by τοιόνδε σέβας she means the reverend court of Areiopagos.

Neither among the Scythians, nor the lands of Pelops, a stately expression for neither in Greece (the Peloponnesus standing for Greece) nor in the distant barbarous countries. So (H. quotes) Soph. O. C. 695 neither in Asian land, nor the Dorian isle of Pelops.

κερδῶν ἄθικτον, incorruptible. The gen. belongs to a special (though common) class of usages with negative adjectives, e. g. ἄλυπος ἄτης Soph. Εl. 990, ἀψόφητος κωκυμάτων Αi. 321, ἄσκευος ἀσπίδων Ε1. 36; a combination of gen. of reference and gen. of separation.

ὀξύθυμος, quick to wrath: a tribunal that delays not to punish. The fine expression that follows, a wakeful guardian of the land on behalf of them that sleep, has been misunderstood [by Schol. and others]: it is simply an imaginative description of an ever-vigilant tribunal, always watchful even when those it defends slumber.
φρούρημα, guardian: for this verbal suffix used actively compare γυναικὸς ὢν δούλευμα Ant. 756.

p.stage: [During the following dialogue the seated judges in turn arise slowly and solemnly, and take their pebbles and drop them into the two urns (τευχέων 1. 742).]

div.p: βαρεῖαν τήνδ' ὁμιλίαν χθονός, these dread visitants of the land. χθονός somewhat loosely but naturally after ὁμιλίαν. The Chorus' language is mild: but the threat is none the less effective.

ἀκαρπώτους. The notion is often found in the ancient poets that the will of destiny or the gods could be thwarted by man's perverse- ness: thus in Homer people act or suffer ὑπὲρ μόρον : and in Vergil the 'fates' of one side conflict with the 'fates' of the other.
Thou hast respect to deeds of blood-not thine office, mean- ing that he protects the murderer, and so interferes with the functions of other deities, viz. themselves.

No longer from a pure oracle shalt thou prophesy. We must read νέμων for the awkward μένων of MSS. with H. D. Hart. Kirch. Weck., etc.; νέμων will then govern μαντεία. The word ἁγνά is much more applicable to μαντεῖα in the sense of shrine than in the sense of prediction.

For Ἰξίονος see note on 1. 441. The argument is, Did not Zeus succeed in purifying a murderer who was a suppliant once before, viz. Ixion? προστροπαῖς, in the supplication.' Dat. of occasion, used by poets, e. g. νόστοις, ‘at his return, Soph. Εl. 194: τόκοισιν, in child bearing, Ο. Τ. 172 : λόγοις τοιούτοις, at such talk, Antig. 691. It is obviously closely allied to dat. of time, of respect, and of cause.
μὴ τυχούσα, of course conditional: if I do not...
ὁμιλήσω, will haunt, will visit.

Pheres was father of Admetos: and the reference is to the famous and beautiful story of Alkestis, in Euripides' version as follows:-Apollo having served in the house of Admetos, by order of Zeus, and being well treated, repaid his debt by begging off Admetos' life from the Fates, on condition of his finding a substitute. After trying all his friends he found none but Alkestis, his wife, ready to die for him. See 1. 172, note.
ἔπεισας. Euripides says (Alk. 12) that Apollo cheated (δολώσας) the Fates; and (1. 728) Aeschylus tells us it was by making them drunk. The crude barbarism of the tale points to its great age.
σέβοντ', pious. Euripides (Alk. 10) calls Admetos similarly ὅσιος ἀνήρ.

τύχοι. The common use is to employ the opt. in past general conditions, the subjunctive where the verb, as here (έστι understood with δίκαιον), is primary. But it is a special idiom to employ the optative in maxims and other statements of a universal character, where the verb is to apply to all time: or to put it otherwise where the idea of time is absent. Thus
Soph. O. T. 315 ἄνδρα δ᾽ ὠφελεῖν ἀφ᾽ ὧν ἔχοι τε καὶ δύναιτο κάλλιστος πόνων, ib. 979 εἰκῆ κράτιστον ζῇν ὅπως δύναιτό τις. So Ant. 666, Trach. 93, Ai. 521, 1344. So Thuc. 1. 120 σωφρόνων ἐστιν εἰ μὴ ἀδικοῖντο ἡσυχάζειν.

διανομάς, ordinances: the MSS. have δαίμονas, but the Scholiast on Alkestis 12 quotes the line with διανομάς; and this certain emendation was thence made by Cobet. δαίμονας was suggested by θεάς in the next line.

σύ. τοι is scornfully repeated. οὐκ ἔχουσα τῆς δίκης τέλος, 'failing to win thy cause' is the general sense. τέλος literally means the decision, as in 1. 243; and having the decision' means winning it.
ἐμεῖ. is future.
καθιππάζει, characteristic vigorous figure, override, i. e. overbear.
ἀμφίβουλος οὖσα, ‘doubtful,' undecided.
λοισθίαν κρῖναι δίκην, to give the last judgment, i. e. vote; δίκη in a slight but natural strain of meaning.
[Here Athena holds up a white pebble.]
εἰμὶ τοῦ πατρός, extended use of the gen. of possessor: I am for the father, on the father's side, which would ordinarily be πρὸς τοῦ πατρός. 6

Thus Orestes wins, even if the votes,' etc. The regular rule of the Athenian dicasteries: it is part of the poet's purpose to repre- sent the court and all its customs as of ancient and divine institu- tion.
[The question has been much discussed whether Athena's vote is counted among the ballots, or is the casting vote; some even maintain- ing that she does not vote at all.
At first sight it would appear that Athena votes (1. 735), that the votes are counted (1. 742), and that with Athena's the votes are equal.

But this would make the court an odd number: the majority in the judges against Orestes; and Athena interfering to turn a majority into a minority:-all of which are very unlikely, and spoil the impressive symbolism of the vote of the goddess. This, as Müller (Eum. Append.) has pointed out, is as follows: The human justice is divided about the cause: the guilt of Orestes, the guilt of Klyt. balance: it is the goddess who gives the casting vote. Thus the rule that equal votes acquit is finely and imaginatively explained: when the earthly ψῆφοι are equal there is an unseen and divine vote for mercy.
This could easily and simply be brought out in the action: the other judges get up and drop their pebbles in, Athena holds hers in her hand until the counting.]
πάλους, lots, only an imaginative word for the pebbles: so much turned on the decision.

p.stage: [Here two judges rise and turn out the votes.]

div.p: The cries of suspense on either side are significantly ad- dressed to Apollo, God of Light (φοῖβος), and Night, mother of the Furies.

ἀγχόνης τέρματ', death by the noose, the most miserable death; the form of tragic suicide adopted by women when all is lost, e.g. Iokaste (O. T. 1264), Antigone (Ant. 1221), Phaidra (Hipp. 777). Helena however (Eur. Hel. 300) says: ''Tis best to die: but how to die nobly? Hanging in mid-air is unseemly-'tis held shameful even among slaves.' ἀγχόνη is consequently proverbial for the last and worst suffering : κρεῖσσον ἀγχόνης Ο. Τ. 1374, ἀγχόνης πέλας Heracl. 246, ταῦτα δῆτ᾽ οὐκ ἀγχόνη; Ach. 125. ἀγχόνης is gen. of description or equivalence, like the Homeric τέλος θανάτοιο.
γάρ. explains their cry 1.745: 'For 'tis ours to be lost, or yet more honoured.'
πεμπάζω, from πέμπε (old form of πέντε), means 'to count' on the five fingers.

διαιρέσει, the parting of the votes. This word shews that the voting was (as Schol. says) by black and white pebbles, which was the commonest method at Athens. In this system there were two κάδισκοι or urns, one called κύριος or the decisive one, the other ἄκυρος: each voter had a black and a white pebble; his vote was counted, according as the pebble he dropped into the κύριος was white or black, for acquittal or condemnation. The second or 'inoperative' urn was to get rid of the other pebble, that there might be no clue to the way he had voted. Another method was by an urn of acquittal, and an urn of condem- nation: but this would require only counting, no διαίρεσις.

If a vote fail, great sorrow comes: the cast of one pebble saves the house; a picturesque and rather loaded way of saying one vote either way makes the difference between ruin and salvation. The picturesque word βαλοῦσα, as though the saving pebble touched or struck the house is quite in Aeschylus' vein of sudden and bold metaphor. ὤρθωσεν, gnomic aor. [Others following Schol. take the last line 'overthrows and uplifts the house, but the expression is very harsh for this].
[As she speaks, she adds her white pebble to the votes of acquittal.]
The man is an Argive again.'
ἕκατι, ‘by grace of,' the older Epic use of the word, always with God's name, by will or aid of, like Διὸς ἕκητι. So Cho. 214, 436. τοῦ πάντα κραίνοντος is of course Zeus Soter.
ὁρῶν. seems rather weak: Weckl. reads παρείς.
ἅπαντα πλειστήρη χρόνον, a stately expression, all the fulness of time.'
The oath that no Argive king shall ever bring an army against Athens of course refers to the recent treaty, see note 1. 673.
κεκασμένον, Epic word, arrayed.
Being then in the grave, the τότε referring to any future time when the friendly Argives should become foes, and 'lead the arrayed spears' against Athens.
vῦν is part of the attribute: τἀμὰ νῦν ὁρκώματα, ‘my present oaths:' the attribute may be always so divided. See note on 1. 653. Notice the Epic syncope of παρά in παρβαίνουσι.
πράξομεν, we will so deal; ὡς μεταμέλῃ, 'that they may repent:' the παρβαίνουσι depending on the general sense. But the expression is harsh, and perhaps corrupt.
Giving them marches of despair and ways of evil augury; this fine line a fuller explanation of ἀμηχάνοισι δυσπραξίαις.

ὀρθουμένων. might refer to the oaths, if they are kept,' as the Schol. seems to mean [γεννωμένων, which is prob. corrupt for γενομένων], but is probably vaguer, if all be well. The change to dat. τιμῶσιν is a little loose in structure: but not so unnatural here where the subject is changed.

The whole passage 11. 767-774 is suspected by Dind., but the diction is mostly very Aeschylean, such lines as 768 and 770 particularly: the only noticeable things being the obscurity of πράξομεν and the somewhat superfluous αὐτοῖσιν, αὐτοῖσι. But there is certainly no ground for rejecting the passage.
πολισσοῦχος. (like πολιοῦχος) is regularly used of gods, Theb. 69, 185, Ag. 338, but in this play it is used three times (11. 775, 883, 1010), of men, citizens.
ἄφυκτον. with πολέμιοις, a struggle wherefrom thy foes ne'er shall escape.

p.stage: [Orestes and Apollo go out: the Areopagites remain seated, Athena in the midst.]

div.p: [THIRD STASIMON. Ye younger gods, ye have trampled on the ancient laws. From my wrath a blight shall come on the land. Alas, we are mocked and dishonoured.]

Wanting in V. Fl. Va. It is clear that it is not this
refrain but the second repetition (11. 808-822) that V. Fl. Fa. copied, as they follow M. G. in reading erroneously ἀντιπαθῆ 1. 812, and ἐπεσσυμένος 1. 816, whereas M. G. have the correct forms in the first refrain.
εἴλεσθε, i. e. you have stolen him, Orestes my prey.

ἐν γᾷ τᾷδε, upon this land : it seems from 1. 800 as if it was meant to be taken here with βαρύκοτος, 'falling on this land with grievous wrath.' The ἐv is the Epic use with verbs of motion like ἐνὶ στήθεσσιν ὀρούσας: cf. πίτνων ἐν δώμασι Cho. 36, φέρουσ᾽ ἐν ἡμῖν Ag. 1450, and again below ἐν χώρᾳ βαλεῖ 1. 787.
ἀντιπενθῆ, woe for woe. So the gloss in the Med. rightly explains, ὁμοῖα δρῶντα οἷς πέπονθα.
The participle μεθεῖσα has no verb: the verb, as happens occasionally in these long broken sentences, is deferred and finally appears in a different form 1. 789.
A leafless childless blight-ah! justice!-speeding o'er the land shall scatter on the ground the deadly plague-spots.'

MSS. read: στενάζω; τί ῥέξω; γένωμαι· δύσοιστα πολίταις ἔπαθον. Perhaps the best emendation is γελῶμαι, I am mocked, a natural exclamation, as Antig. 838 οἴμοι γελῶμαι. [This is adopted by H. D. Hart, etc.] δύσοιστα πολίταις ἔπαθον, Grievous to the city shall be my wrongs, i. e. the city shall pay for my ill-treatment. This is the Scholiast's explanation, and perhaps the best.
[SCENE IV, Part 2 (broken by the stasima). Athena addresses the chorus between each song, soothes and entreats them, and promises them a home and honour in Athens. At last they yield.]
ἀληθῶς, ‘truly:' i. e. there was no fraud or evil intent, but the honest decision.
ἀλλὰ ... γάρ, elliptical as usual, the ellipse easily supplied 'but (you lost) for there was witness,' etc.
ὡς, regular poetic use for ὥστε.
The MSS. show signs of a confusion of order, and I take Weil's correction as the most natural restoration.
Athena soothes them, and persuades them not to execute the threats, 11. 780-782.

δαιμόνων σταλάγματα, if right, must mean immortal venom: the word δαιμόνων emphasising the supernatural and terrible power of the blighting drops. The word has been much emended, the best suggestion being Wakefield's πλευμόνων or λαιμάτων : for, as Hartung
says, the expressions in this speech are largely determined by the Chorus, and the corresponding phrase is (1.784) καρδίας σταλαγμόν.

Corroding stings, devastating the seed; a fine characteristic line. It is best thus to make the gen. dependent on ἀνημέρους : the latter word meaning wild, waste, and here, by a common stretch of usage, applied not to the αἰχμάς but to their effects. For the masc. form βρωτήρας with fem. αἰχμάς compare τύχη σωτήρ Ag. 664, Ο. Τ. 80: see note on 1. 186.

ὑπίσχομαι, promise, for the common form ὑπισχνοῦμαι, somewhat as οἴχομαι οἰχνέω, λήθω λανθάνω, φεύγω φυγγάνω, πεύθομαι πυνθάνομαι. [Heath, followed by Herm. Schöm., read ἐνδίκους : but the MSS. gen. is finer: Athens, as the Athenians were fond of boasting, was the ' righteous' land: so O. C. 1006 εἴ τις γῆ θεοὺς ἐπίσταται τιμαῖς σεβίζειν, ἥδε τοῦθ᾽ ὑπερφέρει. So again below 11. 869, 920.

κευθμῶνας, cavern, grot. There is a chasm or hole in the rock, with a dark spring of water, on the N. E. side of the Areiopagos. This is no doubt the place constantly referred to as the κευθμών or θάλαμοι (1. 1004) of the Eumenides: and explains the phrases κατὰ γᾶς σύμεναι (1. 1007), τοὺς ἔνερθε καὶ κατὰ χθονὸς τόπους (1. 1023), γᾶς ὑπὸ κεύθεσι (1. 1036). The clearest reference is Eurip. Elektr. 1270, where he speaks of the Eum., defeated in this trial of Orestes, as 'entering a chasm of the earth close by the hill itself:' δειναὶ μὲν οὖν θεαὶ τῷδ᾽ ἄχει πεπληγμέναι πάγον παρ᾿ αὐτὸν χάσμα δύσονται χθονός.

λιπαροθρόνοισι, ‘with shining seats' [not with oil as Müller, etc., for the regular libations to the Eumenides were honey and water, fully detailed in Soph. O. C. 470-481], but merely bright or splendid marble seats for the great goddesses.
δύσκηλον, lit. ‘hard to charm:' i.e. past cure, as Schol. δυσθεράπευτον.
The Chorus had called on justice: Athena replies I too have trust in Zeus: though her appeal is rather to threat of force.
MSS. give εὐπειθής here and Ag. 274, Cho. 259, etc. The form seems the regular one, and there is no need to alter to εὐπιθής.
The MS. reading will hardly stand. I adopt (with Weckl.) Burges' correction: Utter not words which bring the land this fruit, that in all things she fare ill.
The black billows bitter violence; a splendidly imaginative phrase for the fury of the Eumenides.

The προτέλεια or marriage offerings made by the bride's family were offered to various gods, Hera, Artemis, the Fates, and
here the Furies, no doubt to propitiate: and we gather that similar offerings were made at birth of children. πρό, is for.

παλαιόφρονα, of ancient wisdom, Aeschylean compound, applied Suppl. 593 to Zeus. κατά τε γᾶς is the best emendation. The indignity which the Furies complain of is being banished to this κευθμών, to dwell beneath the earth.
In the MSS. φεῦ comes before μύσος, which breaks the dochmiac foot and is impossible, though the Scholiast seems to have read it there.
It does not much matter whether we put it before the line, or after, or suppress it. I follow Weil in reading it before.
δâ. is Doric form of γῆ. So Ag. 1072 ὀτοτοῖ πόποι δᾶ.

I adopt (with Franz, Lin. P. Weil, Weck.) L. Dindorf's brilliant conjecture τιμᾶν δαναιᾶν, ancient honours, for the meaningless δαμαίων of MSS. 'The gods' unconquerable wiles have reft me from my ancient honours as of no account.'
ἀπό is separated from the verb aἴρw and draws near to the sub- stantive, as in Epic: one of the forms of the so-called Tmesis. In prose it would be ἀπῆραν. The verb simply means carry off, take away.

συμφέρω, here used in the rather unusual sense of endure, not resent: the English idiom (which in meaning exactly suits this place), I will bear with thy wrath, is only superficially similar. Somewhat like this use is πάντα συμφέρουσ᾽ Ἰάσονι Eur. Med. 13, συμφέρειν τοῖς κρείσσοσι (‘comply') Soph. El. 1465, οὐδέποτ᾽ εὐφραν- θήσεται ἀνὴρ ἐὰν μὴ τῇ γυναικὶ συμφέρῃ (agree) Ar. Lys. 166: the metaphor being [Verrall, Eur. Med. 1. c.] probably of a yoke-fellow pulling with, and not against, one.

I take Wieseler's excellent emendation καὶ τῷ μὲν εἶ συ, i. e. 'and by that (old age) you are far wiser,' age and wisdom being naturally united. So the Scholiast explains the line διὰ τὸν χρόνον, i. e. wiser by lapse of time.
ἐλθοῦσαι., conditional, if you go.'
δόμοις Ερεχθέως, the Erechtheum or great temple of Erechtheus (famous mythical hero-king of Athens), stood on the Akropolis.

ὅσων, ‘such honour as.' Pauw's and Paley's emendation of ὅσην MSS., a reading which will not construe, and is due probably to an attempt to alter the awkward collocation of genitives. The gen. ὅσων is attracted to the case governed by τεύξει. 1. 86ο. ἀοίνοις ἐμμανεῖς θυμώμασιν, ‘raging with fury not of wine,' but implanted by the Eumenides. This highly Aeschylean phrase
does not agree with νέων, as in sense it should but with characteristic boldness is transferred to θηγάνας αἱματηράς, 'the whetstones of blood- shed,' as he calls the frenzy of the Furies, by another bold and imagi- native figure. ἀοίνοις is specially appropriate to the Furies, as they were goddesses who tasted no wine, 1. 107.

ἐξελοῦσα, which has been immensely emended, is no doubt right: the idea is simply as though taking out the heart from fighting cocks and planting it in the citizens , establish civil war, etc. (the cock being the pugnacious bird who will fight with his own kin, and so an emblem of civil strife): only the rapidity of Aeschylus's style makes him compress the two last clauses into one.
For the domestic broils of the cock see line 866: and Pindar, Ol. 12. 20 ἐνδομάχας ἀλέκτωρ.
οὐ. μόλις παρών (lit. ' coming not stintedly'), no scanty store: i. e. for foreign warfare, let us have plenty of it : but not civil dissension. So οὐ μόλις ἀπώλεσας Ag. 1082.
The sense is of home birds' battle I will have nought. οὐ λέγω, lit. 'I do not advise, or bid,' is a μείωσις for ‘I forbid.' [The passage in Soph. El. 1466 which comm. quote is different.]
θεοφιλεστάτης, see 1. 805.
πολισσούχοι, see note on 1. 775.
The soothing and spell of my tongue is in apposition to the Majesty of Persuasion, Πειθοῦς σέβας. The whole sentence is in the imaginative grandiloquent style, and simply means if I can persuade you.
σὺ δ᾽ οὖν μένοις ἄν, dramatic [if I persuade you], 'well then, abide.' [The dé in apodosis is originally Epic usage, common in the Poets: so Ag. 1061 εἰ δὲ μὴ δέχει λόγον, σὺ δ᾽ ἀντὶ φωνῆς, κ.τ.λ.]
γαμόρῳ:. Doric form for γεώμορος.

The change from lyrics to iambic dialogue on the part of the Chorus marks the progress of persuasion. They have left off mere lamentation and resentment, and begin to consider the offer. ἔχειν, I have, vivid use of present, for I am to have.

ἀπήμον' οἰζύος, gen. after neg. adj., a common use: a com- bination perhaps of gen. of reference with gen. of emptiness or separation. So ἄπαππον πυρός Ag. 311, ἀμήνιτον θεῶν ib. 649, ἄσκευον ἀσπίδων Soph. Εl. 36, ἀψύφητος κωκυμάτων Αί. 321, etc.

καὶ δὴ δέδεγμαι, lit. 'there now, I have received,' dramatic particles used idiomatically when a case is put or supposed 'suppose I have accepted,' 'say now, I consent:' so καὶ δὴ οὔτις ἂν δέξαιτ᾽ Cho. 565, καὶ δὴ τεθνᾶσι Eur. Med. 386, καὶ δὴ παρεῖκεν Hel. 1059.
ὡς. for ὥστε, as often, see 36.
ξυμφοράς, ‘the fortunes,' used neutrally, without a bad mean- ing.
γάρ is 'yes, for,' as often in dialogue. So 1. 899.
It is open to me not to say, I have no need to say.

Weil ingeniously proposes κατᾶσον οὕς for κατὰ χθὸν᾽ οὖσ᾽, charm with a song those whose love thou shalt win, which leads up to the question in the next line. But the MSS. reading will stand; the gist of these lines being as follows (11. 898-903):
Cho.
Will you promise it for ever? Ath.
My word is enough. Cho.
I think I will yield. Ath.
Then you will be loved. Cho.
[now appeased]‘What blessings do you bid me pray for?
ἐπίσκοπα, such as look to, hath regard to no dishonourable victory; a vivid word for befit. The word is similarly used Cho. 126 εὐχὰς πατρῴων δωμάτων ἐπισκόπους, Aias 976 ἄτης τῆσδ᾽ ἐπίσκοπον μέλος.
The νίκη is explained by 11. 864-6: he means victory over foes, not in civil broils: and the next line extends it to all sort of pros- perity.

'Ay, and that from earth, and watery sea, and heaven [all be blest], and gentle gales with fair sunshine blowing may pass o'er the land.' The rapidity in this fine and poetic passage again rather obscures the grammar, though not the sense: the fact is, he was going to say '[and pray] that from earth, sea, sky, and winds [all may prosper]:' but the clause about 'the winds' is specially developed, and the sentence ends differently from what was intended.
ἐπίρρυτον, abundantly, predicative adj.
But the impious be more ready to weed out; the metaphor of ἔκφορος, carrying away, is probably from gardening, as the next line explains.
ἀπένθητον, predicative.
σοὔστι, the regular crasis for σοὶ ἐστί. τῶν ἀρειφάτων . . . πόλιν, and in the glorious strife of war I shall not suffer but that my city shall be honoured among men as victorious.
The gen. ἀγώνων is gen. of respect, put provisionally at the beginning and depending ultimately on ἀστύνικον.
Note τιμᾶν, active according to Greek idiom: they say, I shall not allow but that [people] shall honour my city: we say, 'I shall not allow my city to be unhonoured.'
EXODOS. The Chorus, appeased, pray for blessings of all kinds on the land and people of Athens: the train of Athena's at- tendants, led by the goddess, escort the Furies to their new home.]
Παλλάδος ξυνοικίαν, i. e. to dwell with Pallas.
῎Αρης. is specially mentioned, no doubt because of the Areio- pagos, the scene of the latter half of the play.

There is a fine boldness about the expressions which Aeschylus uses for Athens, 'the fortress of the gods..., the glory of the Powers of Greece, the saviour of their altars;' an imaginative rendering of the favourite idea of the piety' of Athens 11. 805, 869.

This prayer closely follows Athena's suggestion 11. 906-8, 'that the bright sunshine make to blossom up from the earth the bless- ings of life in plenty.' ἐπισσύτους (lit. rushing on, used of the springs of tears, Ag. 887, and of the throes of vain sorrow, Ag. 1150) corresponds to ἐπίρρυτον 1.907.
ἐξαμβρῦσαι. (from ἐξαναβρύω used transitively) is Pauw's probable correction of the meaningless readings of MSS. It is adopted by H. Weil, Lin., Schütz. Well.

κατανασσαμένη, middle, housing in my city. 11. 932, 933. The MSS. read
ὁ δὲ μὴ κύρσας βαρέων τούτων
οὐκ οἶδεν ὅθεν πληγαὶ βιότου.
Now τούτων here must refer to the Furies, as αὗται above and τάσδε below: and consequently βαρέων must be wrong, as (1) it is the wrong gender: (2) even if we suppose (with D.) a fem. form βαρεῶν, it clearly is the wrong sense. What Aeschylus means to say is, He who incurs the wrath of the Furies meets with unexpected calamity: the sins of his fathers bring him into their power.

We must take therefore some emendation like ἱλαρῶν (Weil.), χαροπῶν (Weck.), τῶνδ᾽ εὐμενέων (Hart.): of which I have preferred the former. βαρέων will perhaps have arisen from confusion of β- and ιλ-: or per- haps from a gloss. Another question arises about the metre. Hermann, followed by most edd. (Lachm. Franz. Pal. Hart. Merkel. Weil.), has assumed that Athena's anapaestic stanzas, which alternate with the lyrics, correspond. There are five such stanzas: the three middle ones (at 11. 949, 968, 988) are all the same length: and the first and the last would be exactly equal, if after βιύτου we read some words like προσέπαισαν (H.). The practice is not uniform: thus in the κομμός in the Choephoroi the anapaestic alternating stanzas do not correspond, though roughly about the same length: on the other hand in Aga- memnon (11. 1448-1577) the anapaests do correspond.
It is on the whole more probable that the latter is the case here: and I have accordingly adopted H.'s προσέπαισαν.
The sense then is, He who finds them not propitious is stricken with calamities he knows not whence: and μὴ ἱλαρῶν κύρσας is really a euphemism for offended.
Note the effective antithesis between the 'silence' of the ruin and the 'loud boasts' of the unfortunate man.
χάριν, ‘boon,' blessing.

Corrupt. Some of the commentators (H, Schütz. D. Pal.) try to translate it as it stands: 'Let a blight killing the germs of plants [come not near] to prevent them passing their bounds,' i. e. to prevent them growing: surely an impossible interpretation: a plant does not 'pass its bounds' by growing. The general sense is plain, 'No blight come near'; and perhaps we might accept Wecklein's very ingenious λοπῶν for τύπων: ‘... killing the buds of plants that they pass not the bounds of their husks.' But the sentence is still awkward, with no verb. The other emen- dations proposed are not convincing.
MSS. read εὐθενοῦντ᾽ ἄγαν. Most edd. take Dobree's εὐθενοῦντα ya, but Meineke's suggestion Πᾶν is nearer to MSS. and rather more likely.

γόνος δ᾽ ἀεὶ πλουτόχθων, and ever may the earths rich pro- duce .' The bold compound πλουτόχθων is very Aeschylean. The reference is not (as H. P.) to precious metals, of which Athena (whom the Chorus closely follows in their prayers) had made no mention, and to which γόνος would not be so suitable; but simply to the 'produce' in the ordinary sense.
By δόσιν τίοι they clearly mean that out of their abundance they are to give thank-offerings to the bounteous gods.
ἑρμαίαν, for Hermes was the god of good luck (from Homer downwards, Ερμείας ἐφίλει καὶ κτῆσιν ὄπασσε Il. 14.491) : and a wind-fall or godsend was called ἕρμαιον.
ἐπικραίνει, brings to pass, vivid use of present, of a thing now promised.
διαπράσσουσιν., intrans. plain and full is their accomplishment.
βίον ἀμβλωπὸν παρέχουσαι, ‘a life dimmed with tears,' a beautifully vivid metaphor. δακρύων is gen. of respect after adj. ἀμβλωπόν.

ἀνδροκμής, lit. bringing weariness to men,' here a eu- phemism for 'deadly, is a favourite word of Aeschylus, being found with μόχθος (above 1. 248), and πέλεκυς (Cho. 889), and λοιγός (Suppl. 680) in the same sense as here.
κύρια, ‘the rightful power;' the gods they appeal to being such powers as Ζεὺς τέλειος, Ἥρα, ᾿Αφροδίτη. See above 1. 214.
μητροκασιγνῆται, ‘sisters by one mother,' because the Fates (like the Furies 1. 322) were daughters of Night (Hes. Theog. 217 καὶ Μοίρας καὶ Κῆρας ἐγείνατο).
ὀρθονόμοι. [not ὀρθόνομοι from νόμος], the MSS. reading, from νέμω, assigning what is due.
ἐπιβριθής, lit. weighing down upon, falling heavily on: i. e. grievous.
ὁμιλίαις, ‘visitations.'
στέργω, I bless.

ἐπωπάω. is properly to look down on, watch, behold, descry: so Cho. 693, Eum. 275, but, like the commoner ἐποπτεύω, is used regularly of gods or supernatural powers, and gets the meaning 'to guard, guide, direct;' see note on 1. 220.

ἀγοραῖος, God of the gathering, was a name given to Zeus and other gods (Hermes, Ar. Eq. 297, Artemis and Athena, Paus. 3. 11. 9) as protectors of the city life of which the natural centre was the ἀγορά or 'gathering place' (Agam. 90). But as the ἀγορά was also the place for speech (ἀγορεύω, κατηγορέω, etc.) the name here implies god of speech.

And our strife for blessings is victorious for ever.' 'We have before had an ἔρις κακή, a hostile strife: henceforward it will be an ἔρις ἀγαθῶν, a friendly rivalry to do good: and the victory, νίκη, shall be with both; we shall always succeed.'

ποινᾶς ἀντιφόνους ἄτας, the murderous woes of vengeance, the woes of murderous requital; a very Aeschylean phrase, and more natural on the whole than the Med. reading ποινάς, which would make ἄτας gen.: for in any case it is certainly right to take these three words together. [H. P. and others take δι᾽ ὀργὰν ποινᾶς, 'from desire of vengeance,' weaker meaning and more strained usage.]

'And may they give joy for joy, with one heart of love, and to hate with one soul.' An imaginative way of saying, 'May they live in happiness that comes from harmony, having the same friends and foes.' The latter phrase is the well-known Greek formula in making alliances.

MSS. read φρονοῦσιν and εὑρίσκει, no sense. I have adopted the original suggestion of Hermann, accepted by D. Weil. φρονοῦσα and εὑρίσκεις. 'Dost thou then wisely find the path of good words?' i. e. Are you then come to a better mind, blessing instead of cursing?'
The first two lines are addressed to the Furies: the two next are a reflection and then she turns to the citizens.
εὔφρονas, kindly, a reference to their name Εὐμενίδες.
Taking πάντως, the reading of Ven., for the flat πάντες, there is no need to alter further.

'Guiding your land and city in all righteousness, ye shall be glorious.' ὀρθοδίκαιον is predicative. The use of διάγειν is a little strange: but it is not a great extension of its ordinary usage with βιότον, αἰῶνα, etc. We may compare χρόνος διηγέ μ' Soph. Εl. 789, διῆγεν ὑμᾶς ἐν πᾶσι τοῖς κατὰ βίον Dem. 255. 11: and particularly πόλεις ἐν ὑμονοίᾳ διάγειν Isocr. 35 Β. [Paley takes πρέπω active: but it is very common and always intrans. in Aeschylus.]
αἰσιμίαισι, ‘blessings,' from αἴσιμος, ‘right,' meet, good, lit. that which is one's share or lot, from aloa (strong form from ἴσος).

Seated near to Zeus; fine and simple metaphor for the ' righteous' people specially under divine protection. Hermann quotes Aesch. Niobe, frag. 146 οἱ θεῶν ἀγχίσποροι οἱ Ζηνὸς ἐγγύς of the half- divine heroes: and Plat. Phileb. 16 C οἱ παλαιοί, κρείττονες ἡμῶν καὶ ἐγγυτέρω θεῶν οἰκοῦντες.
Wise at last, i. e. having made your peace with us. This is the simplest interpretation, and there is no ground for suspecting the reading. 6
ὑπό. of accompaniment, with, a special idiom either gen. or dat.: καταθάψομεν οὐχ ὑπὸ κλαυθμῶν Ag. 1554, κηρύκων ὕπο Suppl. 238, μαρτύρων ὕπο ib. 934, ὑπὸ πομπαῖς Pers. 58, and below 1. 1034.
See note on 1. 805.
κατέχειν, check : the genitives χώρας and πόλεως are best taken as possessives after the substantival neuter adjectives τὸ ἀτηρόν and τὸ κερδαλέον.
πολισσοῦχοι, see note on 1. 775.

μετοίκοις, ‘newcomers;' the μέτοικοι at Athens being the resident aliens, the word is admirably fit for the Eumenides who were foes, but are newly settled at Athens as friendly powers. Κραναός: the word means rocky and was a favourite name of Athens, Κραναὰ πόλις or Κρανααί, from Pindar's time down (Ol. 7. 151): here it denotes a mythical king or founder, naturally derived from the common title.
βρέτας τοὐμόν, an earlier statue than the great Athena Parthenos of Pheidias; for the Parthenon was not completed till 438. Athena's attendants must be supposed to join this escort on the Areiopagos.

ὄμμα, idiomatic metaphor for delight, hope, comfort, somewhat as we say the flower, using a different metaphor. The eye is chosen as the most precious and beautiful : so ὄμμα γὰρ δύμων νομίζω δεσπότου παρουσίαν Pers. 169, σέβειν ὀμμάτων ὑπέρτερον 1
Theb. 530, ὀφθαλμὸς οἴκων Cho. 934, ὀφθαλμὸς Σικελίας Pind. Ol. 2 18, etc.
Theseus, mythical king of Athens; Theseidae, common poetic name for Athenian.

Athena had promised them (1.856) honour from men (ἀνδρῶν) and women. Hence some (H. D. Weil.) have supposed a lacuna here; and others (Hart. Meinek.) alter παίδων into ἀνδρῶν. There is not enough ground for either. The people on the stage, whether men, or youths, or boys, evidently represent the whole city, as we see from 11. 1010, 1015. Others again think the propompoi are all women, and take παίδων as girls: but πολισσοῦχοι παῖδες cannot be female inhabitants only. As to the question of the name Εὐμενίδες, which is one of Hermann's arguments, see Introduction, p. 21.
The purple robe was no doubt to add to the magnificence and solemnity of the occasion.
εὐάνδροισι συμφοραῖς πρέπῃ, 'may shine forth with pros- perous blessings,' rather emphatic and unusual phraseology.
βᾶτε δόμῳ, pass into your home, Epic use of the dat. local after verb of motion, e. g. πεδίῳ πέσε (11. 5. 82), κυνέῃ βάλε (7.187).

παῖδες ἄπαιδες, the MSS. reading, could hardly mean child- less children, which seems pointless: it might mean evil children, like vᾶes ἄναες: but the real objection to any such word as ἄπαιδες is that here the words in which the Chorus are addressed are specially reverent and honourable. It is best to reject it and then we get rid also of τύχᾳ τε, meaningless and unmetrical, at the end of 1. 1037.
ὠγυγίοισιν, a strange word of obscure origin, meaning ancient.

εὐθύφρονες, ‘righteously minded,' something like the Homeric αἴσιμα εἰδώς, which is also used of persons well disposed. [Of the sug- gested alterations Hartung's εὔφρονες ἀστοῖς is the best: but there is no need to alter.]
Hermann's ξύν is wanted for sense as well as metre: else it would mean 'rejoicing in the torch, which is a much poorer meaning.

This line is thoroughly corrupt and it is hopeless to attempt to restore it with any confidence: I take Linwood's conjecture (adopted by H. P. and others), which is ingenious enough: Hermann translates, Let Peace follow with the light of the torch : or σπονδαί may be quite simply 'libations, the natural sign of reconciliation and joy.

συγκατέβα, has come down to aid, the metaphor being taken from the 'lists' or the contest, as in Cho. 727.
APPENDICES. I. LINES 358-9, and 369-70. In the MSS. we have 358-9 κρατερὸν ὄνθ᾽ ὁμοίως μαυροῦμεν ὕφ' (or ἐφ᾿) αἵματος νέου, and 369-70 σφαλερὰ τανυδρόμοις κῶλα δύσφορον ἄταν. As usual, where metrical correspondence so completely fails that even the metrical scheme is uncertain, there is a vast mass of suggestions, most of which are too far from the original either in metre or letters to have a chance of being acceptable, to say nothing of their intrinsic infelicity. The Schol. on 358 says διὰ τὸ νέον αἷμα. τοῦ νεωστὶ εἰργασμένου ὑπ᾿ αὐτοῦ. This goes far to prove that he read αἵματος νέου (whether with or without ὑπύ) and explained it 'by reason of the new deed of blood,' i. e. Orestes' murder of his mother. On 369 the Schol. clearly has the MSS. reading, but he gives two interpretations, one making κῶλα apposition to ποδὸς ἀκμάν (as is no doubt right), and the other making the last two lines a new sentence. The two best suggestions are Weil's, which I have adopted in the text, and Paley's. 1. Paley reads 358 κρατερὸν ὄντα *περ ὅμως μαυροῦμεν *νέον αἷμα [from an old suggestion of Hermann's], and 369 σφαλερὰ * καὶ τανυδρόμοις κῶλα, δύσφορον ἄταν. Understanding the first passage thus: '[Pursuing after him] though he be mighty, we waste away the new blood stain,' i.e. we persecute him till in time the murder stain grows faint, as Orestes says (ἀμβλὺν ἤδη 238, and βρίζει γὰρ αἷμα καὶ μαραίνεται 280). This makes a fairly good sense, but is open to the following objections:- (1) That the MS. reading ὕφ᾽ αἵματος νέου and the Schol. are completely unaccounted for. One hardly sees how νέον αίμα could have got so corrupted. (2) That the Furies would certainly not say that they 'wore away' the stain of blood, though Orestes might naturally use such a
APPENDICES. plea. The very point of the Furies' exultation all through is that there is no expiation, even in Hades: 'though he fly under the earth he never is free' 175: 'in death he is not over free' 346: and their office is 'a rugged path for dead and living alike' 387. 2. Weil's reading 358 κρατερὸν ὄνθ᾽ ὅμως ἀμαυρ- οῦμεν αἵματος νέου, 369 σφαλερὰ τανυδρόμοις * ὅμως κῶλα δύσφορον * μάταν, has these advantages on the other hand : (1) The gen. αἵματος is kept; and the Scholiast's note is accounted for: indeed, better accounted for than if the MSS. ὑπό were retained, as then there would be no need of a comment on so easy a phrase. (2) ὅμως in 362 is better than καί, as it would easily drop out after -όμοις of the word before. (3) μάταν is a very easy alteration, since the previous word δύσφορον ends in -v. (4) The trochaic metre is peculiarly characteristic of this scheme; see lines 331, 332, 333, 354, 366, 376, 380, 388, 396. Of the other suggestions perhaps the best is one of that usually reckless emendator Burges, who reads μαυροῦμεν νεόαιμον, 'we waste him away stained with new blood. This would account for the first Schol. But there is no trace of the word νεόαιμος. II. The relation of the Medicean Group of MSS. to the Venetian Group. THE question whether the three MSS. which are called above the Venetian group, i.e. Flo. Farn. Ven. (see Introduction, p. 26) have authority independent of the Medicean is obviously important for the purposes of text criticism. We will call the Medicean M, and the Venetian group FFV. It is clear that there are four cases of error which bear upon the argument:- (1) Where FFV have the same corruption as M. (2) Where FFV differ from M and both are wrong. (3) Where M is right and FFV wrong. (4) Where M is wrong and FFV right. It is also clear that if FFV have independent authority, i.e. if they do not spring either from M or a not remote ancestor of M, we should expect to find (4) relatively considerable. If (4) were found to con-
